name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Gunnar Hökmark, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on ranking of unsecured debt instruments in insolvency hierarchy (COM(2016)0853 – C8-0479/2016 – 2016/0363(COD)) (A8-0302/2017).

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you very much. And I would like to thank the shadows because this has been a very rapid process, a fast-track, in order to ensure that we can very quickly have legal certainty in place on what to do when a bank is in deep problems. I think an important point of departure is the fact that in the European Union investments are far too low. Investments are at a pre-crisis level. I think it is important to understand and to see that this in itself means a systemic risk and a risk of financial instability. Because, if investments are too low, competitiveness lags behind and jobs are lost, but we are also lacking the growth we need in order to ensure stability in the economic system and the financial system. And that is why it is important to ensure that banks can be stable and at the same time have the strength and opportunity to finance investments. In the European Union, banks are crucial for this. We have more banks that are crucial for investments than in other economies. Our capital markets are of that kind. That is why it is important that banks can make investments, create markets, can in all ways ensure that we have the investments and the growth that is needed.  This legislation, that we are to adopt today, is about ensuring that when a bank is in deep problems, there will be no discussion that governments or taxpayers shall finance the problems of others. And this is in itself an extremely important signal to markets. First of all, it is a way of ensuring that when you are in trouble, you know what to do. That is why we have this ranking. And that is why we have the Bank Resolution and Recovery Directive (BRRD), because that is how we tell the market that we are going to bail in or do something else with the banks, but not lean on governments. But a second thing with the BRRD which is, for me, extremely important is telling the market – those who invest in a bank, those who own a bank – do not get into the belief that someone else will save you. This in itself is creating a market discipline that is crucial. My aim with the banking package we are now dealing with is to ensure that we introduce total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC). This will mean even higher security and certainty on what to do when resolving a bank but no higher capital burdens beyond that. Because if we go down that route, it will mean less investment and less opportunities for growth. But the legal clarity we achieve with this hierarchy will safeguard depositors, safeguard taxpayers and will make it known among everyone in the market that you take the same risk when you invest in a bank as when you invest in another company. That is how simple it is. I would once again like to thank colleagues for the very rapid process, because it is important that we have this cornerstone in the banking union in place. Now we have some other things to do in order to complete the banking union, the financial market and the banking legislation.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the House very much for its efforts to solve this issue.  As Mr Hökmark already said, the basic idea in this legislation is to make the market economy more healthy, to show where the risks lie and also to create a more solid rule base for the problems which may arise, as happens every once in a while in the market economy. But this piece of legislation does not overshoot the regulation. It just clarifies who is responsible, and for what.  This will enable banks to build up buffers that can absorb losses when the bank fails, without jeopardising financial stability, and without burdening taxpayers. Banks will issue debt under the new statutory category available in all EU Member States. The debt will be ranked just below the most senior debt and other senior liabilities, for the purposes of resolution. It will remain part of the senior debt category, but as an unpreferred tier senior debt.  Clear, harmonised rules on the position of bondholders in the bank creditors’ hierarchy in insolvency resolution will facilitate the bail-in being supplied, by providing greater legal certainty and reducing the risk of legal challenges. This measure will give banks clarity so that they can build up buffers to absorb losses and protect taxpayers. It is also a key, and most cost-effective, way to comply with the global standard on total loss absorbing capacity, which requires global systemically important banks to build up a minimum level of buffers to be used in resolution. Our ambition is to allow banks and investors to take full advantage of the opportunities of our single market to issue and buy debt, through harmonised solutions.  Once again I would like to thank Parliament, especially Mr Roberto Gualtieri and, of course, Mr Hökmark, as rapporteur, and all the shadow rapporteurs for this file. This was one important piece of the entire banking package. We still have a lot of work to do to finalise the whole banking package and we have to keep working together in a fast and comprehensive way.

name: Pedro SILVA PEREIRA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is not every day that legislation is done quickly and well in the European Union. Therefore, we must not fail to point this out when we have the opportunity. The truth is that this legislative proposal, which reviews the hierarchy of creditors in the event of resolution, achieved this almost miracle: not only was it adopted in an accelerated procedure, but it managed to gather a broad consensus, both in this Parliament and in the dialogue we established with the Council and with the Commission. I want to thank the rapporteur, my colleague Gunnar Hökmark, but also the rapporteurs - shadow of the other political groups, for the excellent work we had the opportunity to do together. This legislative proposal is important and necessary. It aims to improve the rules of the so-called bail-in, the internal bailout of banks at risk of bankruptcy, which were created to protect taxpayers' money. These rules need to be clear. We have changed the creditors 'hierarchy to create a new category of senior non-privileged debt, which increases the banks' ability to absorb losses and achieve the necessary recapitalization. I must say that the socialist group is particularly satisfied with the fact that the contractual maturity of the new class of senior non-privileged debt has been fixed at least one year, with the fact that grandfathering has been established, that is, the new criteria for eligibility may apply to previously issued debt instruments. It was also clear that the debt issued by banks under the previous national legislation, but which complies with the requirements now set, may occupy the same position in the creditors hierarchy as the new category of debt now created. Finally, and very importantly, it has been clarified that nothing in this directive affects the possibility for Member States to give increased protection to deposits. I therefore think that we have a good solution and we hope that it can be continued in the revision of the DRRB Directive.

name: Brian HAYES
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I would like to firstly congratulate Gunnar Hökmark for this negotiation, which was brought about in the informal trilogue process but also as part of the banking package. I think it is important that the agreement that has been obtained across the House sends a strong message in terms of how we are going to deal with it, were a crisis to emerge again. It is absolutely clear, when one looks back on the financial crisis 2008-2009-2010 that we did not have the architecture, we did not have the rules, we did not have the instruments as a European Union to respond to that particular crisis.  Coming from a country that went through an appalling banking crisis, where the Irish taxpayers had to bail out the Irish banking system to such a huge level, for us it is crucially important that we moved to a bail-in process. What I very much welcome about this particular instrument is that there is now clarity on the question on non-preferred debt but also on the categorisation of that debt and how that is to work. Had we had that clarity at the time, as part of a bail-in regime, we would not have found the difficulties that were there for our economy – but other economies as well – going through that crisis.  I think it is crucially important that this instrument is now in place, that there is agreement from the Commission, the Council and Parliament on this matter. It is part of the banking package which now seeks to intensify further banking union, which has to be at the heart of all that we are trying to achieve as a modern economic bloc within the world and having these rules with such clarity allows us to do that.  So my congratulations to my colleague, and to other colleagues who worked with Mr Hökmark and indeed the Commission on this very important matter.

name: Stanisław OŻÓG
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! The Polish delegation in the ECR group supports the proposed amendment to Art. 108 of the Bank Recovery and Resolution Directive. The existing regulations do not regulate the issue of subordinating unsecured senior debt to claims arising from other forms of unsecured debt. However, such regulation is necessary if we want global banks to implement the total loss absorbency standard in 2019. The new regulation will thus facilitate the application of the EU provisions on debt cancellation or conversion, especially in cross-border situations, and in the EU single market it will give international investors and global banks the most desirable thing for them, i.e. legal certainty. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the need to monitor the implemented regulations to ensure that they do not bring excessive burdens on financial institutions.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, this directive harmonises the position of unsecured claims in the context of normal insolvency proceedings. This issue became necessary within the framework of the Banking Union and the Single Resolution System, which provides that all financial institutions, said to be systemic, may have a sufficient level of total loss-absorbing capacity. This proposal has the merit of being consistent with the principles and objectives of the Banking Union to replace the logic of bail-out with the alternative logic of bail-in, that is, to ensure a resolution without resources from public funds, it is necessary to safeguard that each institution can present in its balance sheet a set of high quality assets that guarantee the coverage of losses and keep the bank functioning, at least in its basic vital functions. The problem is that the creation and operation of the Banking Union has not only prevented the use of more public funds, but has also promoted the concentration of the sector, increasing the weight of institutions called too large to fail. It is not by chance that the discussion of a backstop mechanism to give solidity to the whole system is on the agenda. That is, everything contrary to the proclaimed objectives. For our part, we continue to believe that only public control of the financial system can put banking at the service of the economy and not the other way around.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, for my parliamentary group the development, application and improvement of the DRRB Directive is essential. We must strengthen this framework to avoid, as the rapporteur has said, that taxpayers' money is used again to massively bail out the banks. I do not want to recall the data, for example, that in my country the Bank of Spain has recently given: that the Spanish bank bailout cost the Spanish Treasury 60 billion euros, which is practically 6% of GDP. We are concerned, however, because this framework currently has implementation difficulties, and not only because of what has happened recently with the Venetian banks, which, in the end, as they did not want to go to the resolution and went to the liquidation through national law, have ended up costing the Italian taxpayer 5 billion euros. Or there is also the case of Banco Popular. As we saw, at the moment the holes in the application of the DRRB are very large: Mrs. Koenig recognized us, for example, that in the case of Banco Popular, when she asked for the list of funds and assets available to operate the dance- in, because that list was not there, it did not exist, it was not available. And that is a problem. Therefore, progress must be made in strengthening the DRRB, in which this Parliament is united in defending its respect and, obviously, what we decided with today's package is a step forward, because it will allow banks to improve their loss absorbing capacity without recourse to public money. The only thing I have to regret is that we wish the new senior non-preferred product that we created had been classified as a complex product under the MiFID criteria to protect small investors. It is something that we will return to shortly because we have the second BRRD package and we are going to resubmit that amendment. But despite this, I want I would like to thank the rapporteur for the work and my group will give its approval to this legislative package.

name: David COBURN
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, the aim of this directive is to ensure that the global, systematically important banks have the loss-absorbing and recapitalisation capacity necessary to help ensure that the critical functions can be continued without public finances or financial stability being put at risk, and it is a very good idea. Simply speaking, this report is advocating bail-ins as opposed to bailouts.  As a libertarian, I am in favour of a bailing-in system. Ordinary taxpayers should not bear the burden of a financial crisis caused by banks which are too big to fail and too politically connected to fail. This is still the case in many European countries. In Italy, for example, some of the smaller banks were saved only a few months ago by using taxpayers’ money. It seems that not many lessons from the banking crisis were learned. As a Euro—sceptic, I do not believe in supranational policymaking in general, although Brexit will enable Britain to make our own laws to help keep the financial system in the United Kingdom stable. Nevertheless, I hope EU countries ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: Mr Coburn, thank you. May I say that the cough does you good because your voice was even louder than usual.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, with this measure, once again, in my opinion, an opportunity was lost to correct, at least in an important way, some distortions of the previous regulation, therefore of the BRRD and the bail-in, and to correct above all, in my opinion, one of the biggest errors of the BRRD and the bail-in, namely its retroactivity. I would have preferred that the new instrument, which is called in this case the senior non-preferred bond, was a newly issued instrument for all banks, in order to create a capital buffer to absorb losses, large enough to, in fact, to exclude from the bail-in, in an important way, all the amount of senior debt issued before the entry into force of the BRRD and which unfortunately ended up in the hands of savers who in some cases had to suffer huge losses. It was decided to take another approach which, in my opinion, will lead to negative results in the future. Calling senior a product that is actually senior does not risk creating distortions in the sale of these products to savers or in the packaging of these products into financial instruments that end up in the hands of people who are unable to adequately consider the risk. What is done with the bail-in and BRRD legislation, unfortunately, does not protect savers and does not protect taxpayers either.

name: Paul TANG
text: – Mr President, this is an important piece of the puzzle. We are trying to establish, or what we are trying to work on, is the principle that if you take risk, you cannot shift the cost somewhere else. Bankers take risk; they cannot just catch a return but they need also to carry the cost. That does indeed mean that we aim for a bail-in and not for a bailout, most certainly not by taxpayers. That is a principle, that is clear, but that requires work and I am very pleased to see this proposal and the good work. I would like to thank Mr Gunnar Hökmark and the shadow rapporteurs for their work because what we need is a very clear debt hierarchy. This requires amending the legislation. I am pleased to see that we have taken a step forward; further steps need to be taken forward. This is also important because we need protection for investors. There should be no misunderstanding about which is senior, which is non—senior, and we have seen this in several countries. We need to take further steps, no doubt, because I am still convinced that we should not bet on one horse, not just on the bail-in, but also look at own capital, at the leverage ratio of our countries, including the Netherlands where the leverage ratio is still very low, and you could say a pre-crisis ratio. So, once again, this is a step forward and we need to take further steps.

name: Pirkko RUOHONEN-LERNER
text: - Mr President, the report before us is an essential part of the process of normalizing the financial markets after the crisis.Non-performing loans and systemically important banks continue to threaten financial market stability and the sustainability of the recovery.The text agreed in the trialogue is part of a banking package drawn up as part of the construction of the Banking Union.I am not in favor of new solidarity loans, and the new type of debt created by the Member States will not.A new type of debt is needed to meet globally agreed debt hierarchy requirements to cover losses in liquidation situations before other debt obligations excluded from the ability to cover the total loss of the largest banks, such as derivatives, collateralised deposits or tax liabilities.The report is a small but important step towards easing the burden on taxpayers in future banking crises.

name: Bernard MONOT
text: - Mr President, the Banking Union aims to cut off the possibility of reciprocal support between commercial banks and the Member State where they originate. This federalist deepening comes after the rupture of the political and economic link between European nations and their central banks, which dates back to the Maastricht Treaty, and prohibits any possibility of direct support of a state by its central bank. In both cases, the point is to remove any financial recourse and economic support that a state may receive, in order to increase the pressure on the financial markets. Market discipline should, in the German mind, force states to adopt austerity fiscal policies. Conversely, since the BRRD, it is definitely forbidden for States to support their banks in the event of financial difficulties. We believe it is crucial to go back. The European Union will never succeed in putting in place a functioning banking union. It is therefore in the interests of citizens and states to break up the banking union as quickly as possible. Rearranging the internal legal order of states in order to harmonize the hierarchy of bank creditors is therefore not going in the right direction. Voting against this text is for us a vote of coherence in the defense of savers against bail-in.

name: Neena GILL
text: – Mr President, the directive we will vote upon later today is critical. It will ensure that taxpayers will not be hit by the possible insolvency and the resolution of a bank. When a bank is failing or insolvent, the new rules will create a creditor hierarchy, a new category of unsecured debt, as well as a harmonised approach towards bondholders. Many people in the EU, and in particular in the UK, have been victims of mis-selling of financial products, which, in the end, appeared to be bail-inable. These new rules will make sure that clients and investors will be better protected by clear mention of the risks and the inclusions in the prospectus. I am concerned by some supervisors trying to overstretch their powers, as we have seen with the Single Supervisory Mechanism (SSM) in the last couple of weeks, and sometimes with the European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA). Therefore, it is key that we, as a legislator, make level 1 legislation as clear as possible, and I believe this legislation meets this criterion. Therefore, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur and the negotiating team. I hope this directive is a first step towards an ambitious EU banking reform, ensuring that the banks become more resilient, less risky and supportive of the sustainable economy.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the recent financial crisis has been dealt with under the well-known system; the taxpayers themselves have rescued banks in Greece, Spain, Italy and other countries. So, after the taxpayers rescued the banks, now the banks are attacking the taxpayers, who are of course in a difficult financial situation, there is a plethora of red loans and now these people are losing their homes. This is the big political scandal we have seen in the last ten years. In Greece, in fact, additional privileges have been given to banks. When they go bankrupt, the claims of the banks now take precedence over the claims of the employees, the claims of the insurance funds and the government. In addition, Mr Katainen, let me tell you this: now the banks in Greece will grant loans and will cover 75% of the properties that are put up for auction. That is, the "crows" will now take a 75% loan to buy the houses of the impoverished Greeks and we will have a new generation of red loans.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Mr President, when this Parliament adopted the Bank Rehabilitation Directive and the Bankruptcy Resolution, our concern was to avoid contagion and access to taxpayer money, by allowing bail-in. At the same time, for this to be viable, market conditions have been worsened or, in a way, strengthened with the rise in both European legislation and international standards, with the prospect of entry into force of TLAC. Therefore, we had to organize the rise of a market allowing players to be ready in order to have the quality of debt allowing them to meet these obligations. In fact, several member states had launched their own reform in anticipation of the European response, and the banking sector, since the agreement at the Financial Stability Board (FSB) at the end of 2015, was affected by the TLAC requirement. The markets themselves - as evidenced by the large volumes of TLAC-eligible debt successfully issued by banks - reacted and anticipated the effects of this reform. The idea is to allow banks to build up subordinated debt cushions improving their resolvability, without unduly constraining their financing costs. This is why we can, I believe, be happy that this Parliament has helped to implement this new type of debt in an accelerated manner so that the actors can prepare themselves. Of course, there have been questions raised in trying to use this accelerated vehicle which we will have to deal with when we get to the substantive review of the BRRD directive but, at this point, I believe that the key is to enable market players and the market itself to anticipate the entry into force of new international standards.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, indeed, we have experienced repeated banking crises, which taxpayers have moreover remedied, and it is high time, it seems to me, that Europe legislate to first protect consumers.and their deposits, then to allow the banks to guarantee their internal stability, but it seems to me even more important, moreover, to allow the banks to lend to the economic world in order to boost employment in Europe.This legislative text has the merit of being balanced to meet these three objectives.By implementing a hierarchy of creditors, we will stabilize the banking network, but we must not forget that in Europe we need a central regulatory bank as well as parliamentary control of all banking movements.

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: – Mr President, I welcome the proposed amendments to Directive 2014/59/EU under opinion as this represents a very much needed effort to implement the total loss-absorbing capacity (TLAC) standard, which was adopted by the G20. I believe that in order to avoid legal uncertainty the TLAC standard requires that liabilities may be eligible for TLAC only if they are subordinated to other liabilities.  As such, I support the proposal for Member States to ensure that ordinary senior debt instruments and other unsecured ordinary senior liabilities have a higher priority ranking in their national insolvency laws than the new non-preferred senior class of debt.  Finally, it is of utmost importance for the Commission to assess whether it is necessary to make further amendments with regard to the ranking of deposits in insolvency, at the latest three years after the date of entry into force of the Directive.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for this discussion. It showed that it was very consensual. We all more or less all support the principles and the text of the legislation. There are three main points: firstly, it will create legal clarity for bank debt holders; secondly, it will strengthen the internal market and banking sector; and thirdly, it protects taxpayers. Sometimes when discussing these kinds of issues, people feel that it does not make sense that banks take too much risk, and that is why banks are bad and they want to fail. This is not the case. Banks usually do not want to fail on purpose, but we have to understand that banking is just like any business. It may fail, for various reasons, and that is why we have to have an orderly manner to solve these banking problems.  The taxpayers’ role is also very critical here. Taxpayers have sold banks, i.e. investors in the banks, shareholders of the banks, who are usually normal European citizens. There are also sometimes other businesses which have invested in the banks so we have to make sure that the European market economy is functioning well and it has a solid rule base, and even if we are talking about the banking sector, it does not mean that taxpayers should have a greater responsibility to savers, owners, investors or creditors of the banks as they have responsibility in other sectors of business. So this piece of legislation creates much-needed clarity and once again I want to thank this House for its good cooperation.

name: Gunnar HÖKMARK
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, a few points: this is in some ways a complex piece of legislation with a lot of details, but it is not magic. With this legislation we are not avoiding risks, because financial markets and banking are about analysing risks, taking risks and distributing risks: that is the whole idea. But what we are doing with this legislation – and Mr Tang touched upon this – is ensuring that the risk stays with the risk-taker.  That is the main purpose of this and the purpose of the hierarchy, because it describes the different levels of risk. This means that, as Mr Pereira said earlier, depositors will have the least risk, will be the most safeguarded, with the owners in the first hand and then the subordinated debt. This is not magic, and it is my firm belief that, when we are asked to proceed with the rest of this banking package, we shall underline that all debt is bail-in-able, because that is creating market discipline. But we shall also ensure that we have clarity, which means that banks can be transparent but also secure, so that they can finance the investments we need, which are needed in the next step to secure financial stability. Thank you very much for this debate. I look forward to the decision which we will take later today.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place shortly. (The sitting was suspended at 9.38) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo CASTALDO
text: in writing.- The current European banking resolution system focuses on the perverse bail-in mechanism and, if banking separation is not implemented first, the only reform capable of introducing a credible and concrete alternative to bail-out and bail-inon citizens' savings, we will not support other changes, which, in fact, would sound like a legitimization of the status quo.The revision under discussion also presents critical aspects.Given the introduction of a new class of debt securities that will be involved among the first in absorbing losses in the event of a bail-in, no substantial and concrete guarantee is in fact provided to protect retail customers, nor are there any requirementstransparency which clearly indicate the highest riskiness of this class of instruments.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: written. - The reform of financial services after the financial crisis of 2008–2009 included a directive establishing a framework for the recovery and resolution of credit institutions and investment firms (BRRD). These legislative documents created a framework to effectively manage the recovery and restructuring phase of distressed financial institutions, thereby reducing their negative impact on financial stability (contagion effects) and public finances (taxpayer-funded bailouts). This is achieved through the “bail-in”: a mechanism in which either debt is written off or liabilities are converted into equity according to a pre-defined hierarchy. In order to ensure that sufficient financial resources are available for write-downs or equity conversions, the BRRD requires that financial institutions set a minimum requirement for own funds and eligible liabilities (MREL). However, the rules for secured senior debt and newly issued debt are very different in each Member State, with the result that unsecured debtors and creditors are treated differently across the EU. With this proposal, the bankruptcy creditor hierarchy is partially harmonized. This changes the ranking of senior unsecured bank debt holders eligible for BRRD compliance so that bank debtors and creditors are treated more equally across the EU.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: - Mr President, I wish to speak on a point of order.Today, after this plenary session, there are those who have to catch planes.Voting time is at eleven thirty and it has been delayed.We are delaying the debate because neither the Commission nor the rapporteur are there, which I do not understand, but that later endangers the votes.I just want the record.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I am aware of this and the fact that we are sitting here does not mean that we are not trying to take the necessary steps. As I have said, I apologise, but I do not have any means other than making phone calls, and this is what we have been doing. I can see that the Commissioner is with us and the rapporteur is on her way. We can proceed even without the rapporteur, and we will come back to her. Commissioner, I would appreciate it if we could start. The rapporteur is on her way, but I think that we should keep more or less to the timetable. I hereby resume the sitting.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: The next item is the report by Ms Stevens, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on implementation of the European Disability Strategy (2017/2127(INI)) (A8-0339/2017).

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, honourable Members, this Commission has put inclusive growth and social fairness at the core of its agenda. We are working hard to make sure that no one is left behind.  People with disabilities face a much higher risk of social exclusion than the greater population. Across the European Union, the employment rate for people with a disability is around 48%, only 27.8% have completed tertiary education, and one in three people with a disability is at risk of poverty. This is a situation we cannot accept; the gaps are too big.  On 17 November, the Commission, the Parliament and the Council proclaimed the European Pillar of Social Rights. It represents a powerful joint commitment to everyone’s rights, including people with disability, to equal treatment and opportunities.  The Pillar highlights the right to income support, which ensures that people can live in dignity, to services that enable people to participate in the labour market and in society, and to a work environment that is adapted to people’s needs. The Pillar will also contribute to the implementation of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Our work-life balance package is a concrete example. It will help informal carers, often women, to better balance professional and care responsibilities.  The European Commission remains firmly committed to the UN Convention and to its human rights approach to disability. In February 2017, the Commission published a detailed progress report under the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020, assessing progress in its eight areas up to 2016. I am very grateful – and glad, of course – to the Parliament for coordinating such a comprehensive resolution in response to it, and I want to congratulate, in particular, the rapporteur, Ms Stevens.  While our progress report confirms many of your concerns with regard to the situation of people with disabilities in the European Union, it has also shown areas where European action has made a difference. Promoting accessibility in all policy areas is certainly one of them. We can be proud of our achievements with the Web Accessability Directive, with the Marrakech Treaty and in the field of transport and telecoms. We must now see that these instruments are fully implemented.  After two years, it is now high time to take another leap forward with the adoption of my proposal for a European Accessibility Act. Parliament has already adopted its mandate, and I remain confident the Council will also reach a general approach next Thursday. Accessibility and non-discrimination are important building blocks for independent living. Adequate support services are certainly another. European funds offer significant resources to developing the community—based care and services that are essential for independent living. They may not be used for building or renovating residential institutions. The right to affordable long-term care services of good quality, in particular home care and community-based services, is also emphasised in the European Pillar of Social Rights. In this regard, I take good note of your call to ensure that European funds must also adhere, over the next programing period, to the UN Convention and should continue to foster deinstitutionalisation as a matter of priority.  I would also like to mention the work done under the Estonian Presidency on this topic, which should lead the Member States next week to adopt the Joint Council Conclusions on enhancing community-based support and care for independent living.  The last area I would like to mention is free movement. The Cross-border Healthcare Directive contributes to breaking down barriers to the free movement of all European citizens, including people with a disability. The same counts for my proposal to clarify social security coordination applying to long-term care benefits.  Next year, the Commission will also evaluate the pilot project on a European visibility card, which is now up and running in eight Member States. I have noticed that this initiative raises interest and expectations and I am grateful for the support you express. Lastly, I want to say that today’s discussion and your resolution will also enrich our reflection on the shape of future EU disability policies. The Commission is committed to taking the lead in this process and involving all actors, in particular people with disabilities and their representative organisations.

name: Pavel TELIČKA
text: I would just like to make a remark in connection with Ms Estaràs Ferragut’s concerns, which some others might share. We are still well on schedule for the votes as planned.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Reporter. - As 3 December is International Day for People with Disabilities, I would like to be able to discuss my report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy in this plenary session in this House. I would like to say a huge thank you to all the shadow rapporteurs and the secretariat for joining me to meet this deadline. It is so important that we continue to think about limitations and keep inclusion on the political agenda. After all, people with disabilities are not the sexiest item on the agenda and very few politicians like to talk about it. And this while one in six people has a disability to some extent. That equates to 80 million Europeans! Can we really afford to continue to ignore this large group of European citizens? I am indeed talking about citizens, because that is what they are: European citizens. So they should be able to enjoy the same rights as everyone else. The right and the freedom to go to school, work, eat out, go to the theater or the cinema. The right to travel abroad and enjoy their free time with family and friends. People with disabilities should not be second-class citizens because of their disability. Mr President, I would like to ask everyone to please keep in mind that not every person with a disability is as fortunate as I am. They are not always able to tap into their full potential, take the job that they want, live where and how they want or even marry who they want. The EU is effectively one of the most advanced and richest regions on the planet, yet it is not inclusive enough. We unfortunately still manage to exclude so many of our citizens on a regular basis. The result is that we are losing out on valuable skills and potential labor force in the process, while they are more than ready and willing to contribute to our society when given the opportunity. Let's not forget that money is lost due to inaccessible infrastructures, goods and services.Therefore, the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020 is an essential tool in ensuring all our citizens are able to form an integral part of our society and contribute to our society.We need a post-2020 strategy to follow up and it needs to be both bold and effective, because if we don't get it right who will?It is time for action.Let us all work together to make the European Union more inclusive.

name: Rosa ESTARÀS FERRAGUT
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr President, first to thank Helga Stevens and also to the Commissioner for her involvement in this European Strategy that is now in force, and that we have to work on the next one now. I would like to speak on behalf of people with disabilities, especially women. We defend inclusive growth in Europe, that is, no one can be absent; a Europe without barriers and a Europe of equals; That is why it is important that we all get involved in this strategy, that we resolve the gaps in this strategy that is in force from 2010 to 2020, that we adapt everything to the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, because it is the convention where people with disabilities participated and is what we have to follow. For this, this strategy has to be our roadmap and we have to achieve full citizenship, equal citizenship, inclusive citizenship. This means equal access to education, at work, accessibility, participation, respect for dignity, equal opportunities, equal rights. Only in this way will we achieve a fairer Europe.

name: Julie WARD
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. – Mr President, as rapporteur for the opinion on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, I am glad that the final report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy encompasses the main elements that I proposed, namely the mainstreaming of accessibility requirements in EU cultural policies, the need to pay special attention to the difficulties young people with disabilities and special needs encounter from early education through to their transition to employment, the issue of barriers to mobility, the digital gap, and the citizenship aspect. I also consider it useful to adopt a gender perspective in decision-making and to collect gender-disaggregated data related to the situation of people with disabilities and monitoring policies and actions in the field, as well as intersectional data on vulnerable people and those facing multiple discrimination, such as women with disability or disabled people and refugees. As a member of the Disability Intergroup and a champion of the rights of people with disability, I was happy to work on this extremely important issue in collaboration with civil society and with people with disabilities. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Marek PLURA
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Ladies and gentlemen! As shadow rapporteur, I would first like to congratulate my colleague Helga Stevens and also express my satisfaction that we have managed to prepare a comprehensive report. I also want to thank all colleagues who have contributed with the amendments for their commitment. Today we adopt a document that relates directly to the quality of life of Europeans with disabilities and their families, so I believe that it is necessary to create conditions for them to lead the most independent life possible, move away from isolating inpatient care, develop assistantships, inclusive education, personalized counseling and Supported Employment, as well as the available environment, goods and services, which was also emphasized by the Commissioner. Speaking of the exercise of their rights by people with disabilities, today I would like to particularly emphasize civil rights, including the possibility of participating in elections to the European Parliament. Ladies and gentlemen! In a few days, on December 6, the European Parliament of People with Disabilities will be sitting in this room. Over seven hundred delegates from all Member States will present their demands, counting on the fact that we, Members of the European Parliament, will fight for their implementation with full commitment. The opportunity to participate in the elections will be one of the main topics of this important meeting. The report we are going to vote on is not only an assessment of the status quo, but also a commitment to building a Europe for all, a Europe without barriers.

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: On behalf of the S&D Group. - First of all, I thank the rapporteur, Helga Stevens, for her really good work together, and I thank the Commissioner, who really understands that we need to invest more and do more to enable our disabled people in the European Union to have accessible, affordable services for their families. I want to point out four main things. First of all, I believe that adequate social support for people with disabilities is very much needed, and states must provide social support and provide the necessary social services to their citizens with disabilities. Their additional needs and, in most cases, unfortunately, low and low-quality employment simply dictate such a need. States must guarantee at least a minimum income for people with disabilities and their families, as, unfortunately, such support is often the only source of livelihood for them. The basic needs of people with disabilities often lead to significant additional costs compared to people without disabilities, i. y. hiring assistants, additional adaptation of the environment, additional necessary equipment, medicines and many other things. I would also like to draw attention to the employment of people with disabilities. I think no one doubts that people with disabilities want to live an independent, full life and want to work, but usually cannot do so because of their disability and because the labor market is not ready to accept them. We must therefore take this very seriously so that the labor market is accessible to people with disabilities. I also want to point out accessibility. Indeed, it is necessary to adopt and have an accessibility act, because access to public services is very important both for our citizens with disabilities and for the elderly, who often also have temporary restrictions on movement. Public transport, health care, education and social services must be accessible, affordable and of high quality. Finally, additional funding for the integration of people with disabilities is very important, and when we consider the funding period for the next 7 years, additional funds must also be made available.

name: Czesław HOC
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mr Chairman! Special thanks to Ms Helga Stevens for such an important report. In fact, each of us experiences disabilities to a greater or lesser extent, although the modern world is organized by and for non-disabled people. It would be so beautiful and noble if the world of the disabled and the world of healthy people stood on one solid foundation and if they mutually enrich and complement each other. That in this one world we would act to alleviate dysfunctions and at the same time prepare disabled people for active life in the natural environment. After all, disability never means disability. A disabled person is above all a person and is never a cripple, handicapped, or underdeveloped. Always and everywhere, we are to first see a person, a man, then possibly his cart. In Poland, the provisions of constitutional and statutory rank prohibit discrimination ... (The Chairman interrupted the speakers due to problems with translation), inter alia, on the grounds of sex and disability. The existing provisions on broadly understood human, civil and political, social, economic and cultural rights apply equally to women and men, girls and boys. People with disabilities have the right to a normal life, and if they are not incapacitated and their health allows them to do so, they can live in a marriage (understood as a union of a woman and a man), live together, get married and have children. The law enables them and Polish law protects them. According to the Polish constitution, no one may be discriminated against in political, social or economic life for any reasons. In the Republic of Poland, a woman and a man have equal rights in family, political, social and economic life, and public authorities assist disabled people in securing their existence, preparing for work, social communication and special health protection.

name: Marian HARKIN
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first I would like to thank Helga Stevens for her excellent and comprehensive report and her 100% cooperation. Today we are discussing the implementation of the Disability Strategy in light of the ratification of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities (CRPD). Today Parliament gives its perspective on progress to date so that the UN CRPD you can have real meaning for real persons with disabilities, in real time. By that I mean today, now. Life is not a dress rehearsal for any of us and the same is true for persons with disabilities. When we speak about accessibility it must mean that services are accessible, that public spaces are accessible, that public transport is accessible, that technology is accessible, and so on. Otherwise, we are saying to people with disabilities: we will improve accessibility in the future, we will improve accessibility when we have money, when we have time, when we have dealt with all the other urgent issues that need to be dealt with. But the truth is, accessibility is an urgent issue and it needs to be treated as such. This report contains many important recommendations, but because of time constraints I can only mention one or two. To me, the first and most important is that while we have the UN CRPD, the Disability Strategy, the Marrakech Treaty and, hopefully, soon the Accessibility Act, as the Commissioner herself pointed out this morning, we have to ensure full implementation. Other areas that I consider important include: reasonable accommodation; the mainstreaming of UN CRPD in all our legislation and then ensuring compliance with that legislation; and the guarantee that all EU funding programmes will be fully accessible. We need to eliminate the medical model of disability and promote a rights-based model. Finally, we must ensure independent living for persons with disabilities. I am happy to say that next week, on 6 December, when this plenary will host a disability meeting, we can be pleased to discuss this report.

name: Kostadinka KUNEVA
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I feel a slight tightness in my chest now that I am talking to you, because I am afraid that many people think that this is another boring discussion about people with some difficulties. I do not know how loud to say it: this is our life. Do you know how many of these things that are taken for granted and easily, are forbidden and impossible to happen to us, people with disabilities? It will be a given if special measures are taken, such as those we call for in the Helga Stevens report. So we say yes to disability as part of every policy. Yes to mandatory requirements and through public procurement. Yes to greater protection for women, and equality policy must run through disability policy because women with disabilities are twice as vulnerable. Yes to access to the labor market. Yes to the European disability card for the same services throughout Europe, but also to culture. Finally, I propose the exclusion of disability benefits from the Troika's austerity measures and fiscal adjustment policies.

name: Tatjana ŽDANOKA
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I want to point out that this report is a very important step forward for ensuring the main rights of people with disabilities, and I want to congratulate Helga Stevens for drafting it. We consider it very positive that the report mentions the need for a holistic definition and application of accessibility and our Group stands for accessibility in its broadest meaning: accessible, affordable and available. We are happy that the final text includes a call on the Commission to set mandatory requirements on the accessibility of public spaces and especially the built environment. It is also of extreme importance to increase the employment rate of persons with disabilities in the open labour market. We would be glad if real solutions will follow. We are also happy that the report points out that the new Skills Agenda should include persons with disabilities as a specific target group. We nevertheless want to express our concern that the mechanisms to ensure an adequate minimum income for persons with disabilities are not sufficiently examined and considered in this report, although that should be one of the main priorities. We also think an important point, which is mentioned in this document but not fully implemented in the text, is the lack of a common definition of disability. If we had such a definition in the future it could solve a lot of misunderstanding.

name: Laura AGEA
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, first of all I would like to thank Mrs Stevens for her work, which is certainly very far-sighted and very ambitious. Alas, unfortunately, this ambition, which we put into writing how the strategy for disability should become universally conclusive, very often clashes with the realities of many Member States, mine in particular, where the concept of accessibility is still a distant chimera. . In schools, architectural barriers are unfortunately the condition that prevents many children from accessing their classrooms and sharing the time of study and even extra-curricular moments with their classmates. Professional figures able to accompany children, for example in extracurricular activities, today are not regulated and very often they are not professionally adequate to the needs of children with disabilities. Access to work and the ugly, obscene condition in which many workers with disabilities find themselves, suffering discrimination and unfair dismissals, are unfortunately still an objective fact, not to mention the concept of deinstitutionalisation that in my country, today, it seems not only a chimera but something completely unknown, that is the possibility of being able to decide how to live one's condition of disability. Unfortunately, this simply shows us that we are not yet able to think of an inclusive society, where disability is simply a common and universally accepted condition, seen as a resource and a wealth. I hope that the necessary efforts will be made to fill these gaps. Thank you colleague Helga and thank you all.

name: Angelo CIOCCA
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, certainly a lot has been achieved in recent years and we must thank the many associations that have dedicated themselves to this issue. Alas, however, unfortunately much still needs to be done. I'll tell you this by taking to help the story made by a friend last week, which concerns a fourteen-year-old boy, named Marcos, who has the desire to continue his higher studies, but today has the difficulty of having public transport. Marcos has no legs, no arms, and today he lives in the great Milan, but he has the desire to study in a neighboring municipality and, alas, the municipality of Milan, the great Milan, does not give him the necessary transport. Then this House has a civil and moral duty to civilize administrators such as those of the greater Milan, who allow themselves to be distracted from these needs of citizens. Just as this House has a duty to find more resources to deploy for disability and it has a duty to remove the pact of stupidity for the costs incurred for disability. We must ask ourselves, colleagues, whether the deficit or the dignity of a disabled person is more important. We must ask ourselves, colleagues, whether it is more necessary to pay attention to budgetary constraints or the dignity of people.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, the wishes of the European Parliament report on disability, although they start with real problems, are ultimately in stark contrast to reality. Victims of the system are even the disabled, whose situation is deteriorating as a result of the policy of the European Union and governments, aiming for crumbs for cases of extreme poverty and drastic cuts in meeting the special needs of the disabled. It is becoming a challenge for Greece, where new cuts in pensions, allowances, medicines and other disability benefits are being used -by the quartet and the government-, disability rates are being methodically cut by the state services, while government structures for the disabled are underfunded and closed. The new term "functional disability" is used as a cutter of necessary benefits, for active aging of the disabled, ie work for as long as they can endure. Resistance is again required in the exploitation of the needs of the disabled by private interests, invoking market accessibility, for an integrated and exclusively state system of protection of the disabled in order to meet all their needs.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: It is my great pleasure to inform you that a delegation from the Parliament of the Republic of Uzbekistan, our friends and my friends have taken their place in the box for official guests.I cordially greet the Uzbek delegation headed by the chairman of the Senate committee on international relations and economic cooperation with foreign countries, foreign investment and tourism, Mr. Alisher Kurmanov.I am pleased to welcome the representatives of the Uzbek parliament who have attended the thirteenth meeting of our Parliamentary Cooperation Committee.We expect constructive discussions and the continuation of our good, friendly working contacts.Thanks for coming!Thank you for your presence!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: We return to the debate on the Helga Stevens report (A8-0339 / 2017).

name: Heinz K. BECKER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen! With great respect for their work, I would like to thank the rapporteur Helga Stevens and our colleague from the European People's Party, Marek Plura, for the excellent report on the implementation of the European strategy for people with disabilities. On this basis, we want to finally allow the social inclusion of all people in society and on the labor market to become normal. To do this, we must also implement the exactly described steps; this is where the governments of the EU-28 are called upon. I would like to remind you of the directives on audiovisual media services, on barrier-free access to websites, on the European emergency number 112, which by a long way have not yet been implemented by all Member States. Even the websites of the EU institutions do not all have the best level of accessibility. Yes, the report is right: barrier-free access to the labor market begins with adequate education. Member States must first of all take action without delay to train teachers accordingly. At the same time, it is important to consistently convey and implement accessibility and to ensure further training during job interviews and the necessary adjustments in the workplace, but also in the means of transport. It is also about rehabilitation and reintegration into the labor market. After all, unemployment among people with disabilities is significantly higher than those without. So let's start now! I also think it makes sense to anchor the European strategy for people with disabilities intensively in the European Semester in the future. I would like to expressly thank the EU Commission, in particular Commissioner Thyssen, for being fully behind the European strategy and for fully supporting it.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: – Mr President, I am pleased that today we will vote on our report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy. My compliments to colleague Stevens because it is an important report and it shows that we are serious about equal treatment in Europe, that we do not distinguish between types of discrimination because we must abandon all types. I would not be speaking here today if I didn’t think that more can be done. I want to stress two things in particular. Firstly, it is indeed high time that the Council unblocked the negotiation on the European Disability Act, and I do hope this will be the case next week. This must be a strong act because, besides persons with disabilities, it will also need to cover people with functional limitations. The second thing I want to stress is that in the view of the Group of the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats of the European Parliament, disability benefit should not be made conditional upon being employed or not. As it stands, there are too many cases where disabled people cannot afford to take a job because it will actually make their financial situation worse. Employment should not mean the loss of vital benefits which disabled people now often depend upon. Therefore I would say that today’s vote therefore marks the end of the report but by no means will it end our efforts for disabled people in the future.

name: Arne GERICKE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! In order to implement the European strategy for the benefit of people with disabilities, I would like to say a warm thank you to the rapporteur, my esteemed colleague Helga Stevens, for her extraordinary commitment to a barrier-free Europe: Thank you, Helga! We all know that Europe has grown by removing borders and barriers. So do we! Let's create a barrier-free Europe for all people! Nothing is impossible. I hope we can provide impetus for all nations, all regions and federal states, yes, all municipalities, to give everything to guarantee a barrier-free environment. Let's create a real European disability card in the EU! But the barriers are also in our heads. Disability begins where we make it one. Let us live together in the truest sense of the word unhindered. Children give us an example of this. In playing together, they are masters in seeing people and not disabilities. The concerns of people with disabilities deserve their own guideline and quick action - today, not tomorrow.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: - Sir. Chairman! Sunday is International Day of Persons with Disabilities, and I think we should take this opportunity to wish good luck to all those who are celebrating that day, and also take this opportunity to emphasize that it is now about accessibility. Accessibility is the next big battle for people with disabilities across Europe. We have a very good opportunity to do something about it now. Thank you to the Commissioner for bringing up the subject in his time, thank you to Mr Stevens for making an important contribution to the debate with the report that is coming now. The next big step, as I said, is the adoption of the Accessibility Directive, which is before us now and which we have negotiated through, and which is an important, important step towards doing something very concrete for people with disabilities. I am absolutely convinced that with the great support in this House for the report that we have arrived at, and also the report that is coming today, we will be strong in the forthcoming negotiations. Now it's really up to the Council, because I do not think we in the Commission and in Parliament disagree much. Now it is up to the Council, to the Member States, to deliver on this initiative. That, of course, is the great challenge that lies ahead of us, and I must at least probably, as a dealer, do my part to get as far as possible at all.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, people with disabilities face multiple daily problems and, above all, the specific problems of integration into the labor market. Member States must be asked to do much more to ensure precisely the full participation of people with disabilities and on equal terms; in short, without discrimination, as stated in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union. The direction of the strategy discussed today points in that direction, in a good direction. However, great challenges remain for full labor and social inclusion, among others, that the hiring quotas are met, especially in public administrations. The administration itself cannot be another wall that has to be crossed on the way to a decent life. I conclude by reminding the European Council that it cannot continue to block progress on the Directive on combating discrimination. If we want to work for the full social inclusion of people with disabilities, the Council cannot be an obstacle.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - Many thanks, of course, to the rapporteur, Helga Stevens, for her respectful work and, in fact, for all her efforts on the rights of people with disabilities. It is our duty, of course, to work together for the dignity and well-being of all parts of society, even the most vulnerable, and of course people with disabilities, because in the European Union every sixth individual over the age of 15 lives with a certain disability. People with disabilities still point out that many international documents written on the rights of people with disabilities are not provided in practice, especially the social situation of people with disabilities, poverty and the unemployment rate. Therefore, of course, it is to be welcomed that a lot of attention is paid to employment in this document as well. This is, of course, one of the main means of fully integrating people with disabilities into society. Of course, there is a huge, huge amount of room for improvement in virtually every Member State. They also point to the stagnation in the field of electronic accessibility and here the report is clear, this gap must of course be closed. I would also like to draw attention to the complete, or often sometimes, absence of comprehensive national disability policies. We are witnessing mainly ad hoc measures, to which disability organizations are also critical. This is also observed in Slovenia. Commitments made at EU level are necessary, but without good implementation they will only be a dead letter on paper. Therefore, it is extremely important that the report specifically emphasizes the act on accessibility, so of course its implementation is necessary as soon as possible, and above all, of course, people with disabilities should not think only on the day of people with disabilities or when adopting such resolutions. days of the year.

name: Tim AKER
text: – Mr President, earlier this year, the nation’s paper of record the Daily Express obtained figures that showed every week more than 800 Britons are having their disability benefits taken away or cut in half, leaving them unable to work or support themselves. Three thousand people per month are having their mobility allowances reduced or cut, which means, in effect, their cars, scooters or wheelchairs taken away from them. This is the shocking reality of austerity politics in the United Kingdom – that those who have the least are having their dignity and their humanity stripped away from them. On the other hand, however, the British Government is well equipped to find the money to give GBP 1 billion to Northern Ireland. It’s well equipped to find the money for endlessly increasing foreign aid. And, as we know, this week it has found GBP 40 billion to pay the ransom from this place. Only when the government changes will things change in the UK. But, as things continue, it is going to get worse and worse and worse for those who have the least in the United Kingdom.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: - Mr President, a civilization can be judged by the way it treats the most vulnerable, especially people with disabilities, and Europe still has a long way to go in this area. I thank Mrs Stevens for inspiring this beautiful report on the European strategy for the millions of people with disabilities who live in the European Union. I agree with most of his proposals, which almost always respect the sovereignty of states. I agree in particular with the request made of them to ensure accessibility for people with disabilities to buildings open to the public, to public services and to communication technologies, in accordance with the requirements of the UN Convention of 13 December 2006. I myself oversaw its implementation in the field, as a municipal councilor. However, I express regret: I regret that this report is sometimes polluted by considerations which have nothing to do with it, such as for example in paragraph 22 where it is mentioned - I quote - "multiple discrimination resulting from the intersection of gender, disability and sexual orientation ”. I believe that the LGBTI lobby could have had the elegance to withdraw from the real subject of the report: disability.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Mr President, one can only acknowledge the very important steps that have been taken in the field of protecting people with disabilities. The efforts to integrate these individuals into society are now much more systematic than in the past. Therefore, any new initiative to support people with real disabilities can only find me, not just in agreement, but supportive. However, in addition to the situation that we would like to create, we must also examine the situation that prevails in some countries of the Union, such as my country, Greece. As a parent of a child with Down syndrome, I know the situation first hand. In the special school where my child attends, the teachers and staff are unpaid for seven months, there is no heating and the materials for the laboratories are non-existent. The school supplies that the children carry are forced to be paid by the parents, from the already reduced ones, due to their memoranda, salaries and pensions. The same happens in most special schools in my country. What we will vote on today, unfortunately, will be just wish lists. Exclude people with disabilities and their families from the austerity policies in place to prove in practice that people with disabilities across Europe have the same rights and the same care and support.

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: - President! I would like to pay tribute to Mrs Stevens as responsible for the report on the mobility and inclusion of people with disabilities adopted in 2011 and for the European Disability Strategy 2010-2020. This report is an excellent continuation of the work that began at that time. At the same time, I would like to draw attention to the technological revolution that is now taking place around us: these new technologies are effective in helping people to live independently. I call on the European Commission and the Member States to give maximum support to these assistive technologies, their research and innovation. I am convinced that my country, Hungary, is setting an example for the European Union in this. EU funding is earmarked for disability organizations representing people with disabilities. That’s what the slogan “Nothing about us, without us” is about.

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - First of all, I would like to congratulate my colleague, Helze Stevens, on her excellent work on this much-needed report. It is very important that the commitments and measures taken in the European Disability Strategy are actually translated into concrete action. Anyone who, for example, caused an injury for only a few weeks, which, for example, reduced his mobility, knew how complex tasks were suddenly that he would not have thought about in everyday life. As the Social Democrats' shadow rapporteur on the European Accessibility Act, I would therefore like to emphasize that accessibility is one of the key issues. Accessibility of common services and goods, but also of the built environment can significantly improve the quality of life not only for people with disabilities, but also, for example, senior citizens and contribute to their full participation in society. I am pleased that Parliament has voted in favor of the act, and I hope that it will be adopted immediately by the representatives of the Member States in the Council, as this report also calls for. It is also essential to promote inclusive and active access to the labor market and, in particular, to tailor vulnerable groups from the outset in a non-discriminatory manner. People with disabilities remain most at risk of poverty, social exclusion and homelessness. I am pleased that Mrs Stevens's report, with which I have the honor of co-chairing the Parliamentary Intergroup on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities, covers all these aspects. I also very much appreciate the involvement of organizations representing people with disabilities in the preparation of the report. As the motto of the European Disability Forum says: "Nothing about us without us". I would also like to call on all colleagues to work with organizations representing people with disabilities at national level in their day-to-day legislative work. Only in this way will we be able to ensure that their rights are truly represented in all areas and at all levels.

name: Ruža TOMAŠIĆ
text: - Mr. President, people with disabilities are one of the most vulnerable groups in society.Every responsible society has an obligation to work every day on their better integration, raising the quality of life and combating stereotypes.I welcome the report from my colleague Stevens, who did a great job.I will emphasize in particular the part of the report that highlights the close link between poverty and social exclusion of people with disabilities and social rights and the roles of their family members who are often left to care for a particularly vulnerable family member alone, without any compensation or professional assistance.I am extremely pleased that Croatia is making serious strides in this area and I believe that this and similar reports will contribute to an even better understanding of people with disabilities and to raising common standards of their protection and helping their family members who care for them.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr President, years ago, at a meeting on social services, I was lucky enough to hear from a woman in a wheelchair a phrase that changed my point of view on disability: 'Being different does not mean being unequal'. If we are to be successful in any policy aimed at improving the lives of the 80 million Europeans with some functional diversity, it is not enough to eliminate discrimination. We have to guarantee to this enormous group the full enjoyment of their rights. It is not by chance that this is precisely the focus of a document that legally binds us: the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Do you think that, assuming that perspective, we would be here discussing whether accessibility problems should also be solved in built environments? Would anyone be able to defend aloud the "exceptions" that some justify in fields such as health, education or social services? Any of us present here can acquire a functional diversity. Hopefully we can overcome it by breaking the mold. "There are people who call us handicapped who need light": this is how a blind person explained to me why, when the entrance to his house was dark and there was a knock on the door, an alarm sounded. This report looks at disability with that same way of looking: diverse, empathetic. That is why I fully support her.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Mr President, the European Disability Strategy must be seen as an important guiding document in safeguarding citizens with disabilities. We note, however, the criticisms of the disabled organizations and associations, also expressed in the report, on the limited scope of the strategy and its limited scope in the face of the lack of funding for its implementation, and for not contributing to the objectives of employment, inclusion and poverty reduction. In fact, they are those organizations that also claim that the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities has, to date, had no effect on the measures adopted at European level. On the other hand, we reaffirm that strategies and intentions will be of little use if they are not accompanied by breaks with European Union policies, which in recent years have been responsible for the austerity revenues that have dramatically passed on citizens with disabilities and that have promoted drastic cuts in social support, in the attack on public services, in the increase of unemployment, with a consequent increase in poverty.

name: Davor ŠKRLEC
text: - Mr. President, first of all I would like to thank my colleague Stevens for her continuous and persistent commitment to the rights of persons with disabilities and to raising general public awareness of the problems that these persons face. We could say a lot about this report. There are a lot of problems and challenges that are facing all of us, and I would say especially before the Member States. But I think that one of these, meaning accessibility, is very important in exercising the rights of people with disabilities. Accessibility to cultural facilities because we are witnessing that it is very difficult today for people with disabilities to come to the theater, to the cinema, to sports competitions. Also, accessibility in public transport. Their mobility is very important for them to truly become equal participants in our society. And perhaps most importantly, for the next decade we plan to invest a lot in the renovation of buildings and we must not forget that this renovation should include elevators, escalators because in this way we will enable their inclusion not only in society but also in quality housing.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - With regard to people with disabilities, we should obviously agree that, regardless of the country, the physical and financial capacity to ensure a decent quality of life for such people should be equally good in any country in the European Union. In the countries of the European Union, there are still plenty of segregated special schools, special companies that only use business, subsidies for the employment of people with disabilities. But it actually violates their rights to employment in the open labor market. It is necessary to distinguish between disability benefits and financial support. Taking into account the additional care and other needs that people with disabilities may have, thus enabling them to live a dignified life and enter the labor market. We must ensure that disability benefits are never discontinued or taxed, regardless of the benefits we receive. The European institutions today spend significantly more on other purposes than they could support people with disabilities every year. That is at least part of those funds for these very things.

name: Dieter-Lebrecht KOCH
text: - Dear Colleagues! First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Helga Stevens, and the shadow rapporteurs, in particular my colleague Marek Plura, for their excellent work on this dossier. I think that this report has succeeded in highlighting the progress that has already been made, but also the weaknesses that still exist in European policy for and with people with disabilities, and in setting new goals for our work. We should make it our principle to always pay attention to the rights and needs of people with disabilities in the context of everyday work and to continue to work to improve their self-determined participation in all areas of life. It is just honest to make it clear to those affected that the huge advances will not come overnight. We are dealing with a development process. I still remember very well: 20 years ago this topic was completely ignored in the European Parliament. Today we are talking about a whole strategy for people with specific needs, and the issue has reached the consciousness of all MEPs. Isn't that a success across the board? I take a critical view of the call for a horizontal anti-discrimination directive. In addition to many other points, however, I very much welcome the demand that the Europe-wide emergency number 112 must be made accessible to all people, including people with disabilities. This has been close to my heart for many years.

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the European Union must strengthen its role as a promoter of human rights. We must be able to concretely expand the safeguards and guarantees aimed at protecting our citizens in order to give a dimension of complete meaning to our community project. The report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy does just that.
