The broad consensus for Mrs Stevens' work, obtained in the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, shows the commitment of all of us MEPs. This report, drawn up in close cooperation with organizations representing people with disabilities, defines the objectives and identifies concrete and sustainable guidelines for an accessible, inclusive and cohesive Europe of the future, in which also people with disabilities, the elderly and persons with temporary functional limitations are enabled to participate in the social, economic and political life of the community in an active and independent manner. We can and must do more, starting with strengthening inclusive social protection systems, measures to support employment on the labor market, expanding the right to health, inclusion in European programs such as Erasmus Plus and Youth Guarantee. The European Accessibility Act is an important first step and we must defend it. The role of local authorities in implementing these policies is also fundamental, and I want to greet in the stands some mayors of my country, of Italy, of Piedmont, since their role is fundamental in this. Less than a week before the celebrations for the World Day of Persons with Disabilities, today we reaffirm that a Europe of the size of each one is a Europe in which everyone can get better.

name: Marek JUREK
text: - Mr Chairman! All people with disabilities have the right to our solidarity, and we have a duty to do so, because this is why society exists to help those in need. But to contradict this is to question the law, the most fundamental right of people with disabilities, that is, the right to be born. Recently in France, the government of the French state made a decision denying the status of social advertising, denying the right to solidarity, social advertising showing children with Down syndrome talking about their happy life, talking about the love they experience, about happiness, because - as it was announced - this advertisement would hurt women who made another legal decision. Unfortunately, the decisions of this Parliament, which attacked the Polish social society at the previous session, and I would like to emphasize the social legislative initiative concerning the right to be born of disabled children, are part of a similar policy. It is time for the European Union to change this policy, because it is a contradiction of the intentions it officially declares.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, solidarity is today, in modern societies, a political imperative of democratic rule of law. It is not, as it has been in the past, the expression of religious feelings motivated by individual beliefs, but a collective obligation of essentially ethical content. Solidarity emerges from a principle of social co-responsibility, according to which, in a human community, we are all responsible for everyone. It is therefore not surprising that it has come to occupy a prominent place within the framework of the European Union's own legislative initiatives. It is therefore in this context that the European Disability Strategy should be framed. That a person with a disability is, because of that circumstance, different is a fact! But that she never feels diminished in her condition as a citizen implies a responsibility for all other citizens and, above all, for public authorities. All of this stems from the emergence for disabled citizens of a set of rights that are structured as a sign of the many other duties of the State and society in general. Making this universe of rights have an effective normative content in the European Union is a legal-political obligation that depends, essentially, on this Parliament, but that these rights are not reduced to proclaiming ornaments of the legislative preambles or rhetorical flowers of political speeches , but have practical meaning and usefulness for disabled citizens, depends on all citizens of the Union.

name: Kateřina KONEČNÁ
text: - I am fundamentally convinced that the strength of society is determined, among other things, by how it treats those in difficult life situations. People with disabilities face many obstacles during their lifetime and it is the task of a society of solidarity to help them eliminate them. Equality and non-discrimination must therefore be at the heart of the strategy to help people with disabilities. Both in terms of access to health care and access to work, education, social protection, etc., we should not forget, however, those who help them to ensure better conditions, namely family members. These are very often unpaid carers. Personally, I very much appreciate all those who give very physically and mentally demanding help to their family members with disabilities. Ladies and gentlemen, let us take care of people in difficult life situations, because otherwise he cannot talk about the values ​​of civilization.

name: Mireille D'ORNANO
text: - Mr President, disability is a subject far too serious to be satisfied with long and recurrent declarations of intent. Also, I fully support the desire to apply the principles of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities as soon as possible. In addition, national laws and regulations already exist. It is therefore in each State that it is necessary to ensure their effective application. As such, the European Commission will have difficulty in calling for strengthening, for example, the legal obligations of accessibility to public buildings, given the budgetary austerity that Brussels imposes on a certain number of Member States. Although this report is quite comprehensive, it is regrettable that no mention is made of the daily mobility of people with disabilities. We could have recalled the importance of financial aid for the adaptation of vehicles, or the promotion of carpooling in business between able-bodied and disabled people.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: – Mr President, colleagues, rapporteur Helga Stevens, I am convinced that we have to improve the living conditions of people with disabilities. I admire how they are able to overcome obstacles, but they still need to be helped. The key areas are education and employment, that is to say the accessibility of services that enable integration. Involvement in work for disabled people has a positive impact on other aspects of their life and it leads to greater financial and social independence. Employment also simplifies integration and helps to overcome prejudices by society. Therefore, some of the facts mentioned in the report concern me. For example, in some Member States, the work of people with disabilities is not sufficiently valued. Certainly, we understand that they have to develop much more energy to meet their performance targets and do not always achieve the required results, so we should appreciate their efforts and ensure they have decent working conditions. A precondition for integration is equality-inclusive education. That is why I gladly accept the concrete provisions of the report, including Erasmus+ and other youth programmes being accessible to disabled people. It is important to make life easier for people with disabilities through national activities, especially where the EU’s role is limited, such as in the area of social security.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, I would like to congratulate Ms Stevens both for this report and for all the work that she does on behalf of people with disabilities. There are 13 million people in the United Kingdom with disabilities, a disproportionately high number of whom live in the West Midlands, only 3.4 million of whom work. In the United Kingdom you are twice as likely to be unemployed if you are disabled and, if you are not working or not able to work, you are increasingly unlikely to be supported by the welfare system. The switch in the UK to universal credit is having a catastrophic effect on disabled people in just the way that this report talks about in point 61, in point 71, in recital A. But we in these institutions are also not good at dealing with disability and are in no place to lecture. I wrote to the European Commission in September 2015 asking how many disabled people it employs and the answer is you don’t know, because you don’t collect the information. You do an anonymous survey of less than half your staff and it is not good enough!

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: – Mr President, persons with disabilities are denied many of their fundamental rights each day. They suffer from indirect or direct discrimination when they are excluded from society, from work, or even the environment around them. Their labour market access is dismal and often they are directed towards benefit schemes instead of receiving the support needed to enter the workforce. As the report rightly points out, this happens despite the fact that the overall cost of keeping persons with disabilities out of the labour market is higher than including them in the workplace. Unfortunately, instead of improvements, there are still instances in the EU where backward steps are taken. Recently, the Romanian Government adopted an emergency decree which removed the option for companies to compensate non-compliance with Romania’s current quota law for employment for persons with disabilities by buying products from protective employment units. This cost the jobs and livelihood of most of the around 2 000 persons with disabilities working in sheltered employment and the existence of 740 employment and work services for persons with disabilities. This happened in a country where the employment and activity rates for people with disabilities were already well below the EU average. Situations like these make it imperative for us to maximise the implementation of the UNCRPD, improve EU coordination and urgently put in place support measures in all EU Member States.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: - Mr President, having a strategy in the European Union on disability is important, but being ambitious with it and its compliance is even more important. I want to start by recalling that, as of today, we do not have a definition or harmonized criteria in the European Union on what a disability really is - criteria that allow us to establish comparable indicators and data and, with this, clearly implement a strategy comprehensive approach to working with disability - which, in addition, creates inequality among the member states. I must mention the gender issue: again, once again, the weak link in disability is also women. We need a true gender perspective in all disability policies in the European Union, and it would allow me to propose that Structural Funds be used specifically to finance projects in this area. And, finally, I would like to ask for greater attention to children with disabilities and the intellectually disabled: they are people who, from the outset, already have the first barrier, which is to be able to express what their problems are.

name: Krzysztof HETMAN
text: - Mr Chairman! There are as many as 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union. We cannot allow these people to not be able to fully enjoy their citizenship rights. Although work on increasing accessibility and better social inclusion of people with disabilities is progressing, there is still a significant area that needs improvement. We need to complete work on the European Accessibility Act quickly and efficiently, in order to make it easier for people with disabilities to access products and services, and thus enable them to live an independent and dignified life. Activities aimed at increasing the employment of people with disabilities are also particularly important, as the problem of unemployment in this social group is still significant. In my opinion, this situation can change through appropriate incentives for employers, supporting the creation of social enterprises or creating flexible and inclusive working conditions. Increasing the employment of people with disabilities is also possible by ensuring good quality and inclusive education from an early age. In this aspect, the segregation policy should be avoided and architectural and communication barriers should be eliminated. Moreover, given the high proportion of early school leavers with disabilities, a wide range of lifelong learning programs should be provided.

name: Biljana BORZAN
text: - Mr President, there are more than 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union, and more than half of them are women.They urgently need an accessible environment without prejudices.Despite numerous international conventions and provisions of European law, including the existing European Strategy on Persons with Disabilities, persons with disabilities still do not fully exercise their civil and social rights.I would also like to point out that a large number of people with reduced mobility and people with disabilities in the European Union live in multi-storey buildings without elevators.These people are prisoners of their apartments and often their only alternative is institutionalization.I call on the Member States to make use of the European and national resources at their disposal and to make life easier for these people.In conclusion, accessibility and non-discrimination of persons with disabilities should be promoted through the European Union's structural funds.

name: Lara COMI
text: - (IT) Mr President, congratulations also for the Italian, so I thank you twice, and I also thank the Commissioner with whom we have always worked very well, ladies and gentlemen, one of the questions I would like to ask myself is whether Europe is a community that it can be defined as truly civil, if it is enough to speak of freedom of speech, movement, expression and vote, and if this is only the whole concept of civilization. I am here today also to thank the mayors who are always close, in particular, to citizens with difficulties and we have right here in plenary the National Association of small municipalities, which sometimes have very few resources to be able to help those who really they are in difficulty, to eliminate all architectural barriers but also to give them help. Let me conclude my speech by truly remembering a girl, an Italian girl named Ilaria Bidini, who was bullied precisely because of her disability. This girl was awarded the title of Knight of the Italian Republic for her courage. She is a girl who reacted to the shame, I must say, and to the indecency of comments, accusations, threats and insults of young people, but not only of young people, for being disabled. Because of her great strength, today I can say "Je suis Ilaria", because she is an example of how to react. Happiness has no architectural barriers.

name: Francisco de Paula GAMBUS MILLET
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, I would like first of all to thank the rapporteur for the work done and I would like to encourage you to reflect. Legislators must stop thinking, once and for all, that public policies in relation to disability are sectoral policies, to transform them into universal policies. In Europe today there are 80 million people who live with some type of disability, but potentially we are the 500 million European citizens who one day may have to face it. Too many times we face our day to day as if we were perfect and indestructible, forgetting our human character and, therefore, fragile. I insist: the future European Disability Strategy must have the ambition of being universal, not sectoral, with accessibility being key in all areas of our day-to-day life, at home, at work, in transport, on the streets and everywhere. and each of the daily aspects, to guarantee the vital independence to which every person is entitled.

name: Ivica TOLIĆ
text: - Mr President, congratulations to Mrs Stevens and support for this comprehensive report. First of all, it is important to really ensure accessibility, which is a fundamental principle and a basic precondition for the realization of all other rights of persons with disabilities contained in the UN Convention. Recently, I participated in a health symposium of 100% Croatian war invalids, where we finally defined the issues of accessibility in the field of information and communication technologies, all kinds of services, public institutions and other areas in the area. The issue of European Union cards for people with disabilities was also assessed as very important, concluding that it is necessary to expand the pilot project in which only eight EU member states participate to all member states as soon as possible, as well as EU parking tickets. It is important to further apply the principle of mutual recognition of disability in all Member States. Finally, it is important to constantly invest in the quality of orthopedic aids and ensure the accessibility of quality aids for all citizens with disabilities. Changes are also needed in the member states so that the amount of orthopedic aids is a matter for specialists, not regulations.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - The European Disability Strategy carries an important message, as it sets out a strategy to empower people with disabilities so that they can fully enjoy their rights and participate in society and the economy on an equal footing with others. In order to best implement the strategy, the institutions and countries of the European Union must work together to raise awareness of disability-related issues. According to the Association of Disabled Workers of Slovenia and the Statistical Office of the Republic of Slovenia, there are between 160,000 and 170,000 disabled people in Slovenia. The vast majority of health does not allow them to work, and those who could, more than a third cannot find a job, so they depend on state aid, which is very small, so many of them live below the poverty line. 7,500 Slovenes receiving a disability pension is less than 300 euros per month. The state allows these people to receive childcare allowance, but the amount of the total monthly amount is about 450 euros, which is definitely below the poverty line. For people with disabilities, society as a whole needs to do more, regardless of the provisions of the European strategy.

name: Monika BEŇOVÁ
text: - Mr President, the affected fellow citizens in the European Union still have to deal with the many problems and situations that everyday life brings them. The Convention, which the Member States are obliged to implement in full as soon as possible, is important for the rights of people with disabilities. Disabled citizens are often dependent on our help in areas that they would be able to do on their own with better targeted help. A special chapter is and emphasis should be placed especially on women with disabilities. These often find themselves on the brink of poverty and an unworthy life. An even more complicated situation occurs in families where a mother - a woman - is disabled and at the same time some of the children are disabled. That is why we need to talk about setting a minimum income threshold for such families and for such mothers, so that they can live a dignified and full life and so that they can provide it for their children. Attention must also be paid to the care services that disabled citizens deserve and which are often underestimated. Thank you, Mr President.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, 3 December has been established as World Day of Persons with Disabilities, and I think that today's debate, as well as the vote on Mrs Stevens' report on the European Disability Strategy, is the best way to show that European Parliament, that we support people with disabilities and, above all, that we are moving forward with the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. We have discussed many cases of people with disabilities in the Committee on Petitions and I think that the measures we are taking to strengthen solidarity, equality, accessibility, mobility and, of course, support for people with disabilities, as well as remuneration and issues education and training are crucial. Unfortunately, the policy implemented by the Troika in Greece essentially leads to the system now throwing people with disabilities in the social Kaiadas. All disability pensions and all social benefits for the disabled in Greece are limited. The disability movement is fighting hard to support people with disabilities; it is fighting the Troika.

name: Jiří MAŠTÁLKA
text: - It is my duty not only as a Member of Parliament, but above all as a doctor to support and promote every proposal, every measure that will make life easier for people with disabilities.The motion for a resolution on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy is, of course, part of this.It is a sad reality that a number of existing measures at EU level against people with disabilities have not been and are not applied consistently and their implementation has not been monitored to the necessary extent.I believe that we need to be more ambitious in our approach to people with disabilities, at least as we did recently when adopting the so-called Accessibility Act.Promoting the employment of people with disabilities, their non-discrimination and improving the quality of social services must be a matter of course.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, supporting and voting in favor of the report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy is a strong message that the European Parliament stands by and in solidarity with all these people. Because if there is one thing we are proud to belong to and we are Europeans, it is that the European Union is the founder of equality, non-discrimination and the support of all those who really need our support. Culture for us here in the European Union means that all these people have exactly the same capabilities and the same ease that all European citizens have. It means access to education and employment, and in all areas there is absolute and unlimited equality, which must be ensured by specific projects and acts of the European Parliament, but also of the European Union. That is why I consider it very important for the European Union to fund and actively support all these actions and actions. The European Disability Card must be introduced, the minimum guaranteed income for people with disabilities must be introduced in all Member States, and we must send a really strong message that we are in fact next to those who really need our support.

name: Caterina CHINNICI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, the report we are debating today highlights the numerous critical issues which still hinder the full and equal participation of disabled people in modern society and in the world of work. I thank my colleague Stevens for her work and I very much appreciate that you have included specific provisions in your report to protect children with disabilities, who are unfortunately often excluded from the education system due to legal and organizational obstacles. I consider it of fundamental importance that children and young people with disabilities receive not only quality education and vocational training, but also all necessary support from the institutions aimed at promoting employability. In this regard, I am convinced that the European institutions have a duty to ensure that programs dedicated to young people, including Erasmus and the Youth Guarantee, are fully accessible to all children with disabilities and constitute an essential tool for their participation and integration. . Through the implementation of the European Disability Strategy, the Union needs to give a strong signal to all Member States on solidarity and inclusion.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, people with disabilities have equal rights, including inalienable rights to dignity, equal treatment, an independent life and full participation in social life, but too often they face discrimination and obstacles in exercise of their rights. The European disability strategy provides for areas of intervention that are strictly interconnected and, precisely because they are interconnected, if we do not achieve satisfactory results in all areas, we will not be able to say that we have fully achieved it. A virtuous circle must be set in motion capable of fully exploiting the potential of the person, favoring independent life and the full inclusion of people with disabilities and making them a positive and productive element also within the working context. Particularly important is the reference to "after us", a strategy for assisting people with severe disabilities after the death of their loved ones. It is a particularly delicate aspect of the care of the disabled, which my country is already implementing and which the highly civilized Europe, the vanguard of rights in the world, could not and cannot ignore.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to finish by thanking you for today’s constructive discussion and for your valuable remarks. It shows the European Parliament’s strong commitment to the implementation of the United Nations Convention. The objectives of our European Disability Strategy remain fully relevant and we are committed to complete its actions before 2020. By 2020 it is expected that one European citizen in five will experience a degree of disability. The challenge is not becoming smaller, all the more reason to start our reflection on Europe’s approach to implement the UN Convention after 2020. In 2018 I will launch an external independent evaluation of the outcomes of the current strategy. At the same time, we will ensure a structured process to collect the views of stakeholders and citizens. Your resolution is an important contribution to define and elaborate the post-2020 scenario and I count on your continued involvement.

name: Helga STEVENS
text: Reporter. - I would like to thank the shadow rapporteurs and colleagues for their constructive input in this debate today. We all agree that Europe should be more accessible in all areas that are really important to all of us, not just people with disabilities, but all of us. That means accessible education, employment, training, public transport, you name it, spatial planning, shops, media, the internet, goods and services. I would also like to mention Erasmus +. We must not forget that both the European Union and almost all European Member States have ratified the Convention for people with disabilities. But that is not enough. There must also be action. Here in this house many beautiful words have already been spoken about equal opportunities, equal rights for persons with disabilities and also about the importance of inclusion for every person with disabilities. Many Member States recognize this, but let's be honest: when we look at the United States, we must also dare to put our hands in our own bosom and recognize that we are lagging behind enormously. In the United States, people with disabilities can safely go to school, take up a job, with support they can enter a store or the bank. They can go to the cinema, to a museum, to a sports stadium; the list is endless. They can do that without barriers. But when we look at Europe, sometimes the situation is crying with the cap. Many people can only dream of it here. Look at Brussels, at Antwerp, look at Paris, look at Berlin: not accessible! Why the backlog here compared to the United States? I think we need to be more ambitious. People with disabilities are still faced with many obstacles in Europe. In the United States these have long been eliminated. Why is this not possible here yet? Why are those barriers still there? Hear those people there not with then?I think we should face the problems.You know that December 3 is International Day for people with disabilities.Hence my question to you: stand in those people's shoes for one day.Blindfold your eyes, put earplugs in your ears, borrow a wheelchair and then come and tell me afterwards how it is that people with disabilities are still confronted with numerous barriers.We can make a difference for them in Europe.Not just words, but actions too!By adopting my report, we can press for its implementation in the Member States and in the Council and the Commission.I think we must send a clear signal to the Commission, the Council and the Member States that everyone counts.People with disabilities are also full citizens in Europe!

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: I close the debate.The vote will take place today, ie Thursday 30 November 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Isabella ADINOLFI
text: in writing. - The issue of disability is fundamental. Despite the great progress made, also thanks to new technologies and digitization, much still remains to be done to ensure effective implementation of the fundamental rights of the disabled. In this regard, a European strategy allowing for a fruitful exchange of experiences and good practices can bring concrete improvements for all those European countries that still have a lot to do in this field. I believe that the role of the state and institutions when we talk about people with disabilities, and especially young people, must indeed be an active role. It is not conceivable that families and people with disabilities themselves are left to fend for themselves and have to face all the problems and difficulties alone. Concrete gestures are thus needed, such as the ratification, which seems to take place shortly, by the European Union of the Treaty of Marrakech, which aims to facilitate access and cross-border exchange of accessible works for blind or affected people from other visual pathologies. Only with concrete policies and actions can the institutions be credible and not waving empty slogans, only good at feeling right with their own conscience which, however, do not bring any concrete help to those in difficulty.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: in writing. - My compliments to my colleague Stevens on her excellent work. Unfortunately, however, the good intentions put forward in writing, on how the strategy for disability must become universally decisive, often collide with realities, for example mine. The existence of architectural barriers in schools is a condition that prevents many children from accessing their classrooms, precluding them from being able to study with their classmates. To date, professional figures able to accompany children, in addition to not being regulated, are very often not even professionally suited to the needs of disabled children. Access to work and the shameful conditions in which many workers with disabilities, victims of discrimination and unjust dismissals find themselves, are still a sad reality, not to mention the concept of deinstitutionalisation, or the possibility of being able to decide how to dispose of one's own condition of disability, a concept still unknown in my part. This is proof that we are not yet ready as a society to accept disability simply as a common and universally accepted condition. I hope for an institutional and civil relaunch in this direction.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Disability issues are central to building just, supportive, developed societies. The United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities establishes technical and political measures that deserve our support. The European Disability Strategy should also be seen as an important guiding document for safeguarding the rights of citizens with disabilities. But if the paper can handle everything, what is needed and what is needed is to convey the good principles and guidelines there inscribed to the concrete reality in the lives of people with disabilities. And unfortunately, there is much to be done, as organizations and associations of disabled people have been denouncing. The ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities has, to date, had no effect on measures taken at European level. The lack of funding for the implementation of the European Strategy should be highlighted. Funding that is not lacking for other areas, such as the escalation of militarism and arms in progress in the EU. In addition, strategies and good intentions will be of little use if one and the other are not accompanied by essential ruptures with EU policies, which eternalize said austerity and have a dramatic impact on disabled citizens and their living conditions.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. – There are up to 80 million people with disabilities in the EU facing challenges in education and employment on a daily basis. Only 48% of persons with disabilities are actively involved in the labour market and only 28% have finished higher education. The Members of the European Parliament call upon the EU co-legislators to approve the European accessibility act without further delay as a key part of the European Disability Strategy. Inaccessibility causes exclusion from various areas, including culture or transport, and thus limits the possibilities of social engagement. In order to effectively fight segregation in education, participation in the EU programmes, such as Erasmus+ or the Youth Guarantee, should be granted. Furthermore, I call on the Commission to encourage the uninvolved Member States to join the EU Disability Card project, which secures equal access to benefits for people with disabilities across the EU. A high level of awareness is crucial to fully benefiting from the support programmes. Therefore, the local authorities should guarantee the maximum access for people with disabilities to documents and services. I hope the EU institutions will take the lead and ensure that all their websites are adjusted to the needs of visually impaired people.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - In the context of the report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy, I would like to highlight three issues related to my work in the Committee on Culture and Education. Firstly, taking into account the high percentage of disabled people who leave education and training prematurely, it is necessary to extend the offer of lifelong learning, with particular emphasis on distance learning, including e-learning. In addition, measures to facilitate mobility for people with disabilities are of key importance, including providing them with the possibility of: using a disability card in all EU countries, transferring rights and social benefits, and appropriate financial support for mobility under the Erasmus + program. Finally, following the report, I am calling for young people with disabilities to have access to high-quality internships and apprenticeships and to provide them with greater support in finding employment, using European programs and initiatives.

name: Dominique MARTIN
text: in writing. - The objective of this text is a total absence of discrimination for the disabled within the framework of a Europe "without hindrance", with actions in two stages: 2017-2020 then 2020-2030. I obviously support such an approach in principle. But we must not be fooled, this text has a completely different scope: the creation of a market involving 120 million people, exceeding 30 billion euros! Personally, being disabled victim of visual impairment, I want this subject not to be exploited. Furthermore, I deplore the semantic difficulties encountered by the text on the definition of disability. Indeed, the handicap is the sum of the functional and / or cognitive deficits and not, as the text claims, the sum of the obstacles that society must remove in order for the handicapped person to have a normal life. Also, I regret that this text results in a normative cacophony and more broadly, that it exploits the issue of disability and the disabled to justify captive markets.

name: Alfred SANT
text: in writing. – In the aftermath of 2008 economic crisis, austerity policies forced Member States to cut expenditure for care and support services for people with disabilities. In the same period, the Commission developed a ten-year Strategy for people with disabilities, to better protect them and to align the EU with international standards. These principles and guidance in the Strategy hardly match the budgetary cuts under the Stability and Growth Pact. Notwithstanding, at half of its life span, most Member States, likewise the government in Malta, are implementing the Disability Strategy through measures intended for every person with a disability to become an active citizen, with better opportunities in the labour market and better access to educational experience and social protection. The principles and guidance are well embraced across the EU, but the reality is that their full implementation is still hindered by strict budgetary rules. Under the impetus of Juncker’s Commission there is a genuine recognition that the European project needs to put vigour back into its social dimension. My view is that in the 2020-2030 Strategy, the Commission should build on what has been already achieved at national level and include investments obligation for Member States to boost social services and infrastructures.

name: Monika SMOLKOVÁ
text: in writing. - There are approximately 80 million people with disabilities in the European Union (EU), 46 million of whom are women. I am very concerned that up to 75% of people with severe disabilities in the EU do not have the opportunity to participate fully in the labor market, with some groups facing other types of discrimination based on the type of disability. Although access to the highest attainable level of healthcare, without discrimination on the basis of disability, is a fundamental right, people with disabilities continue to face persistent barriers to equal access to healthcare, including a lack of available information on healthcare entitlements, discriminatory treatment by private health insurers, inaccessible healthcare facilities and often lower quality care that is not tailored to individual needs. I support the resolution because I believe that the EU and its Member States should take measures to ensure that all people with disabilities can exercise their rights enshrined in the Treaties and EU law. I expect the Commission and the Member States, by implementing the proposed measures, to ensure that all people with disabilities have the opportunity to fully exercise their rights and to participate and participate in society.

name: Claudiu Ciprian TĂNĂSESCU
text: signed up. - It is known that people with disabilities are people who have long-term physical, mental, intellectual or sensory disabilities, which, in interaction with various barriers, can prevent their full and effective participation in social life, on an equal footing with others. Central to the European Strategy for People with Disabilities is equality and non-discrimination, as people with disabilities face additional obstacles and multiple forms of discrimination and stigma. People with disabilities have complex needs, suffering from a lack of support, protection, communication and information about their services and rights. As these people have lower incomes, higher spending and a higher unemployment rate, positive discrimination measures are needed, including the adoption of minimum employment rates for people with disabilities in the public and private sectors. Thus, the approximately 80 million people in the EU who are often unable to participate fully in social and economic life due to physical and behavioral barriers will be able to benefit from equal opportunities and real social inclusion and participation.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – While equality and non-discrimination are at the core of the Disability Strategy, we must not forget that there still is a long way to go, and that every day that we have not achieved the goals is a day where disabled people are in effect unequal. Simple things that the rest of us take for granted in our everyday lives remain out of reach for people with disabilities. While I welcome the progress that has been made, I remain deeply disappointed that to this day the Marrakech Treaty has not been fully ratified and implemented by the contracting parties, even though it was adopted in 2013. We must be significantly more ambitious in securing the rights of a group of people who are among the most vulnerable in our society.

name: Claudia ȚAPARDEL
text: in writing. – There are an estimated 80 million persons with disabilities in the EU, of whom more than half are women. They all have equal rights in all fields of life and are entitled to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living and autonomy. It is therefore important that the European institutions fight against all forms of discrimination and provide for equal participation of persons with disabilities in society. Consequently, it is commendable that we have made important steps forward and I am also happy to see Parliament taking this ambitious view in the present report. After recently acceding to the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities – and implementing the first European Disability Strategy – I agree that we are more than ever under pressure to offer better conditions to our citizens. From the transport perspective, we need to do more, so that those in need can enjoy seamless, accessible and independent travel. This is in accordance with the EU Treaties that guarantee the right to free movement for all citizens, and refers to everything from the designing of transport vehicles and stations, to providing assistance from the point of departure to the point of arrival at the final destination of a disabled passenger.

name: Valdemar TOMAŠEVSKI
text: in writing. - There are about 80 million people in the European Union. disabled people. All persons with disabilities must have equal rights in all areas of life and the inalienable right to inalienable dignity, equal treatment, independent living, autonomy and full participation in society. Particular attention should be paid to children with disabilities, who must be guaranteed the inalienable right to live with their families, as this is in their best interests. Given that family members often have to reduce or stop working in order to care for disabled family members, support measures for such families should be strengthened. Legal decisions should start with motivating employers to ensure that people with disabilities are treated with dignity and fairness throughout the process, from education and employment. There can be no discrimination in the employment of people with disabilities. Combating poverty and social exclusion of people with disabilities is closely linked to improving conditions for family members, who are often unpaid carers and not considered as employees. We, as Parliament, should pay more attention to this and call on the Member States to present national support strategies for nurses. Across the European Union, it is essential to remove all legal barriers to the functioning of people with disabilities in society in all areas of life, including at work, in order to eliminate all symptoms of social exclusion.

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. - I welcome the adoption of the report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy in the European Parliament. The report clearly and clearly draws attention to the problems that people with disabilities face in society, in the labor market and in their local environment. The report's findings show that Member States as well as the EU institutions are still not sufficiently implementing all the provisions of the United Nations Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. This document of the United Nations represents internationally accepted standards that reflect the living and social needs of persons with disabilities. He emphasizes that the rights of persons with disabilities cannot and must not be less than the rights of non-disabled persons. The report urges the Member States and the European Union to do more to integrate people with disabilities into social life and the labor market. I also particularly welcome the call for disability organizations to be involved in the preparation of the European Disability Strategy after 2020. Only the cooperation of these organizations can ensure that a document is adopted that presents the real needs and expectations of people with disabilities in the European Union and beyond. That is why I also support the warning that adequate funding must be provided for disability organizations and their programs. Only well-organized and financially supported organizations of people with disabilities can carry out their noble mission on behalf of their members.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Dear Colleagues, Last Friday, November 24, a mosque in northern Sinai, Egypt, was the subject of a terrorist attack that killed hundreds of people in prayer. Egypt has recently suffered a large number of attacks, but this was the most serious in all of this country's modern history. On behalf of the European Parliament, I would like to condemn these attacks and express our heartfelt condolences to the victims and their families and our solidarity with all the Egyptian people. The fight against terrorism must be a common commitment of Europe and Africa, as was also underlined the day before yesterday during the meetings that took place in Abidjan, on the occasion of the meetings between the European Parliament and the Pan-African Parliament and during the European Union-African Union Summit. Yesterday afternoon, during the inaugural ceremony of the European Union-African Union summit, there was a minute of silence, which I joined on behalf of all of you. If we want to repeat even a minute of silence now we can do it. (Parliament stands, observes a minute of silence)

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: - Mr. President, dear colleagues, tomorrow, December 1, is Romania's national day, which has a special significance for all Romanians: the creation of the unitary, sovereign and independent national state on December 1, 1918, the fulfillment of a centuries-old ideal of Romanians. I want to thank all MEPs for their cooperation and partnership, all the Member States of the European Union for solidarity and cooperation with my country. In Romania, the support, the support for the European Union continues to be great. Romanians have understood that the future of Europe is closely linked to the future of the European Union and that now is the time, more than ever, for unity and solidarity, for the elimination of any discrimination between Member States, and I am referring here first to the Schengen Area. I also think it is important to draw on the experience of every other Member State of the European Union. In Romania we have a positive experience in dealing with national minorities who, regardless of the number of its members, have a representative in the Romanian Parliament. Ladies and gentlemen, we must work harder than ever to convince all citizens of the European Union that the only alternative to the European Union is a European Union (the President withdrew the floor).

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mrs Frunzulică, thank you.We also join in the good wishes for Romania's National Day.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The next item is voting time.(For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Bruno GOLLNISCH
text: - Mr President, my point of order will relate to Rules 5 to 9, among others, of our Rules of Procedure, as well as to the text relating to the privileges and immunities of Parliament. We are going to vote on a text concerning the immunity of one of our colleagues, Ms. Gomes, an immunity that I will defend personally with many of my colleagues, since the remarks alleged against Ms. Gomes were made in the performance of her duties. The only thing I do not understand is why this case law is valid in relation to Mrs Gomez and that it is not valid when it comes to Mrs Le Pen, Mrs Troszczynski or others who express themselves, of course, as a Member of the European Parliament, but who do not meet with the same goodwill on the part of this Parliament's Legal Committee. This seems extremely shocking to myself, who for a very long time was a member of this legal committee and a member of the special committee known as "Rules, the Verification of Credentials and Immunities".

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr Gollnisch, we are still discussing the budget, but let me point out that it is the Legal Affairs Committee which makes a proposal to Parliament, and Parliament is free to decide what it wants.So democracy will decide on this matter.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Commission.- Mister President!In a nutshell.We have had extensive deliberations and we believe that a decision is on the table today that is acceptable to all institutions.That is why we are promoting it, and I am grateful for the constructive way of working that I have been able to experience in recent weeks.I am confident that with the current decision and the application that has been submitted, a good basis has been created.

name: Matti Maasikas
text: Council. – Mr President, honourable Members, I congratulate you on concluding your vote on the budget for the European Union for the year 2018. The agreement was reached at the Conciliation Committee meeting on 17 and 18 November.  On behalf of our budget negotiator, Mr Kivine, his team, and the whole Estonian Presidency, I would once more like to thank the Chair of the Committee on Budgets, Jean Arthuis, and rapporteurs Mureşan, Ashworth and Geier, as well as all the Members of the European Parliament who have worked hard and in a constructive spirit to reach this agreement.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The joint text on which the Conciliation Committee reached an agreement on 18 November was approved by both Parliament and the Council.The budgetary procedure was implemented in accordance with Article 314 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.The budgetary procedure for 2018 can therefore be considered closed.I therefore declare the budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 definitively adopted.

name: Tunne KELAM
text: – Madam President, it is about updating the report according to the latest developments. The text runs: ‘ports of Hodeidah and Saleef, as well as the airport of Sanaa, are still subject to the blockade’. We have to add now: ‘but have been partially reopened’. It is a small, but positive, development four days ago, and I think this should be noted.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: This concludes Voting Time.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - Madam President!The budget of the "Erasmus +" program has been increased by EUR 24 million, and "Horizon 2020" by EUR 110 million.This is pleasing, especially since the initial debate may have led to a reduction in this important project.On the other hand, what is crucial - from my point of view - is the reduction of these liabilities, which were very painful when they were unpaid.Reducing the disproportion between payments and commitments seems to me the most important success in the debate on this budget.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Madam President, I do support the European Parliament and Council agreement on the General Budget of the European Union, as foreseen for 2018, and thus voted much in favour. As we see, EU commitments for 2018 will be around EUR 160.1 billion, whereas the factual payments are set up at EUR 144.7 billion. In addition, I fully approve the fact that the following year, more resources will be allocated towards enhancing growth, competitiveness and economic cohesion, with initiatives such as the Youth Employment Initiative, and strengthening other fields such as security. I especially support the allocation of an additional EUR 120 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, as well as (I highlight) an allocation of an additional EUR 3 million for strategic communication. I believe these, and other sections of the budget, more or less reflect the EU priorities for the next year.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - Ms. President! There is still a gap between the income conditions and living standards of the so-called newly acceded, former communist or socialist countries and the income and living standards of the old Member States. Therefore, as the European Union apparently sees ex officio, there is a constant flow from lower-wage, lower-income and higher-standard countries to higher ones. I still don’t know what the idea was when the enlargement process began. In any case, it is a fact that it should now be a priority in the budgets year after year to reduce this gap by all possible means. To this end, I would suggest that there be a new Commissioner, an EU Commissioner responsible for cohesion and convergence, and that this be a clear priority for the budget every year, and that there be an 'impact assessment', an impact assessment on cohesion in the budget.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - I did not support this form of the budget in this vote, although there have been some partial improvements, especially in the area of financial savings in terms of administrative costs.Unfortunately, the structure of the budget still remains essentially the same.A lot of money is spent on various soft projects, the impact and significance of which is very dubious and there is no change in priorities.We face a number of problems that are difficult to deal with, such as the protection of the EU's external borders, but there is still a structure of various organizations, projects, activities and initiatives that swallow money but their outcome whenthen we look at the final balance, it is quite pathetic.Unless there is a structural change, I cannot support such a budget.

name: Daniel HANNAN
text: – Madam President, in the 19 years that I have been here, I have spent an awful lot of time in this Chamber voting on these budgetary items. The thing they all have in common is that it is always an increase. There is never a reduction. Now, I could rage about this from the point of view of the hard-pressed taxpayer, but to be honest, that is not going to be Britain’s problem for much longer. Let me, instead, make the observation that these kinds of increases in budget represent a massive misallocation of resources. Every euro spent by EU institutions is a euro not being spent by somebody closer to the ground, with a better sense of what is the optimum way of using capital – and thus does productivity and competitiveness fall across the Union. What is our response? It is to allocate more money to boost competitiveness. Was it Mark Twain who said that if all you have is a hammer, pretty much everything starts to look like a nail? Is it not at least possible that our citizens might flourish if we taxed them less? As Oliver Cromwell once said, ‘I beseech you, in the bowels of Christ, think it possible you may be mistaken’.

name: Jiří PAYNE
text: - Article 5 (3) of the Lisbon Treaty states that the EU should uphold the principle of subsidiarity, iethat all things should be addressed as close as possible to the people, as close as possible to the citizens, that the EU should not do things that can be satisfactorily addressed at regional, local level.It surprises me that we still have items in the budget that finance subsidies for projects that are of purely local importance.Like lookout towers in the valley, like bike paths that lead from nowhere to nowhere, like even nightclubs or stork nests.Are these projects of pan-European significance?In accordance with the principle of subsidiarity, these projects should be addressed at regional level.I believe that the EU is violating its own Treaty of Lisbon in this matter, and this practice should end.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I supported this budget, I am glad that there has been a political agreement on the form of the budget.I also see some positives there, such as more money for Erasmus +, more money for Europol.I hope that this budget will contribute to better internal security for the EU countries and that it will help us to address migration issues.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, I am not satisfied with the EU budget for 2018 because, on 17 November, President Juncker proclaimed the creation of the European Pillar of Social Rights. But proclamation without budget money is just empty words. We cannot see commitment with social content that would be connected with the proclaimed European social pillar in the next budget. Of course, I voted in favour, but we have to stress that the European Union cannot be properly developed without real common social policy.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, dar ndóigh vótáil mé i bhfabhar bhuiséad 2018, agus tá moladh mór ag dul do na Feisirí Muresan agus Ashworth as ucht an jab a rinne siad.  Fáiltím freisin go bhfuil siad ag cur béim ar fhás geilleagrach agus ar jabanna a chruthú san Aontas, agus go háirithe go bhfuil trí chéad caoga milliún anois curtha ar fáil chun fostaíocht a chruthú do dhaoine óga, agus b’fhéidir níos mó más gá.  Tá sé an-tábhachtach aire a thabhairt do na daoine óga. Freisin, d’éirigh leis an bParlaimint an gearradh siar a bhí molta ag an gComhairle a chosc agus dá bharr sin táimid in ann airgead a thabhairt do thionscadail nua cosúil le Cosma, Horizon 2020, agus mar sin de.  Sin éacht maith agus ag deireadh na dála teaspánann an jab seo go bhfuil cumhacht, croí agus crógacht ag an bParlaimint.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this draft political agreement, which I very much appreciate, especially in the Council, because the EU is really capable, I think it proves it.The world is full of challenges, threats we face, and I am glad that the budget is responding to these challenges as well, especially in the chapter on civil rights security.In my opinion, it is important to maintain EU action, and this draft budget for 2018 corresponds to that.I am also pleased that we have managed to maintain a share for cohesion policy, for cohesion policy, because this is a policy that helps to close the gap, and if it were reduced, there would be no funding for the development of the more backward regions.I am therefore glad that this share has been maintained.I also appreciate the item that has been increased for youth employment under the Erasmus program.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: “The other day we saw President Macron giving a lecture and consulting with students and faculty at an African university. The students complained that there are terrible conditions, the air conditioning in the university is not working. A few minutes later, the rector jumped up and left the boardroom for some reason. Macron made a joking remark, "Surely the rector has run away to do the air conditioning." The world press, of course, immediately shouted racism, although the problem raised in the joke is very real: how is the responsibility for developing countries divided between developing countries themselves and Europe? And an even more delicate question: within the European Union, how is the fair burden-sharing shared between former colonists and, for example, Hungary, and other countries that did not profit from the exploitation of the colonies, did not get rich from the misery of those countries.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - On the one hand, we should be glad: we finally have an instrument, an instrument of stability and security, that is, a specific combination of development and security issues.But I would like to point out that the strategy was created in 2003. We are adopting the instrument in 2017. I draw your attention to this because from time to time it takes a lot of time to get to the instrument, to properly operate something that is recorded in certain base documents., great effort - in my opinion, first of all a waste of time.When it comes to security issues, we know why it has become so important.We observe phenomena related to terrorism, illegal border crossing, and various acts of devastation of the sense of peace and security in Europe.It is worth working on such instruments as soon as a strategy is created.Otherwise, we'll be really weaker.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - I would like to justify why I voted in favor of amending the regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing an Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace.Under the current regulation, activities that really help in places of conflict and trouble are funded.As an example, I can cite projects addressing the refugee crisis.I recently visited Turkey, where Syrian refugees are integrated, and I can say that these efforts are going well.I am therefore pleased that the European fund is also being contributed through this instrument.The amendment to the regulation, which I support, therefore brings a substantial change, namely the possibility of financing the security apparatus of third countries.Given the security threats we face not only in the EU's neighborhood, this is certainly more than desirable.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - I am usually very skeptical about various EU external activities.This often hides either the exaggerated ambitions of the European institutions themselves, or of some of the great European players hiding behind European rhetoric, who are trying to multiply their influence on the world political scene.However, I consider this to be a clear exception, which is why I voted in favor of this instrument.Indeed, if the EU's external action is to have any significance, it must focus on promoting and maintaining stability, peace and tranquility, especially in our immediate neighborhood, and this instrument is clearly moving towards this.We will undoubtedly need better feedback, better control of how the money spent was used, but it is basically a good idea.That is why I was able to support her with a clear conscience.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I also supported this proposal.I am convinced that the long-term fight against migration and geopolitical threats to Europe can only be won or perhaps reduced if we are active in countries where these potential risks arise.Whether potential hotbeds of migration or potential hotbeds of mere civil wars.Our activities in third countries, especially in the immediate vicinity of Europe, where those threats are greatest to the citizen, must be.It is good that today we have adopted another tool to be active in countries where there may be geopolitical and security risks to Europe in the future.So I supported the possibility of supporting military forces in third partner countries.It was emphasized yesterday that it was not the purchase of weapons or tools that would directly endanger lives and health.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, security is an important element of stable development, and this proposal is to allow EU budgetary support and strengthen the capacity of military actors in Chad, in Mali and the Central African Republic and so on in order to contribute to the achievement of peaceful societies and sustainable development. Security is a very sensitive area. It is very connected with the internal and external conflicts that could happen in a concrete country, and we must observe the main principle: do not do harm. To be successful, this pilot project should be properly restricted, transparent, controlled by the European Parliament and not financed from Development Cooperation Instrument money. This is our political group’s principle position, and of course I personally voted in favour.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, Dar ndóigh vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála so mar is dóigh liom go dtabharfaidh sé cumas níos mó don Aontas síocháin a thabhairt do thriú tíortha. The Instrument contributing to Stability and Peace was established in 2014 to support the European Union’s foreign policies. It contributes funding for crisis response, conflict prevention, peace-building and to address global threats. The Instrument therefore plays an important role in EU foreign and development policy. The amending Regulation introduces provisions to enhance the capacity-building of military aids in partner countries with EU funds in order to achieve peaceful and sustainable development of societies in concerned countries. I welcome the objectives of the proposal, which are to improve the capacity of partner countries to prevent and manage crises, to improve the effectiveness of EU development actions by working with all security actors, and to contribute to ensuring the respect for the rule of law.

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: - I supported this report because the amendment to the regulation that this report brings, so I think is very substantial and needs to be supported.In my opinion, increasing the effectiveness of our external representations, external missions, our interests, which we have in our immediate vicinity, is extremely important.If these are advisory services to us, the administrative apparatus in these third countries, for example, then I think these are services that we should have supported a long time ago.If we want to reduce security risks and threats, we need to operate in those countries where they arise.If these funds are not used - the name is called the Instrument for Contribution to Stability and Peace - directly for the purchase of weapons, then in my opinion it is necessary to at least use these funds for advice, security, administrative services.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: - Madam President, we have rightly voted in favor of this report because we believe that it is essential to condemn the coalition led by Saudi Arabia, backed by the United States and composed of the United Arab Emirates, Bahrain, Kuwait, Jordan, Morocco, Sudan ... which is the leading cause and cause of civilian deaths in Yemen. Many of these civilians have been killed by means of drones, in operations supported directly or indirectly by members of the European Union - and it must be said here, precisely in this room - such as the United Kingdom, Italy and Germany. Others are killed with arms sold by seventeen Member States, despite calls for an embargo on arms sales to those taking part in this conflict; arms of the Spanish State, the United Kingdom and France, which have precisely increased their supply. We call for an effective blockade and not to sell weapons to Saudi Arabia, for the immediate suspension of indirect and direct supply and for a ban on the use of drones in extrajudicial selective killings. We cannot be complicit in this, and that is why we have rightly voted in favor of this report.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Madam President, today, a new vote in the European Parliament condemning the situation in Yemen. Tomorrow, a new shipment of arms to Saudi Arabia from European countries. Today, a new appeal from the European Parliament demanding the arms embargo passed in Congress years ago. Tomorrow, new weapons and new European-made bombs falling on civilians in Yemen. So is. This is the impact of European weapons. This is the case made to the demands of this Parliament by those who fill their mouths by calling themselves pro-European or pro-European. Member states continue to export weapons to kill, weapons for radical groups financed by Saudi Arabia itself. Last week, precisely in the Basque Parliament, both PNV and PSE said that the arms embargo is the competence of the European Union. And here today they support demanding that the Member States not sell arms. What a dizziness! What a way to get dizzy and, in the end, do nothing! At least the Popular Party, in an attack of sincerity, has not even asked for the embargo in its own Resolution.

name: Jan ZAHRADIL
text: - I abstained from this vote and I will explain why immediately.Because that resolution is not balanced.In it, we deal with a region that produces many instabilities and risks that directly or indirectly affect the situation in Europe.We all know that there are basically 4 powers in the region.It is Turkey, it is Iran, it is Saudi Arabia and also Egypt, which have a certain balance between them, and one of these powers, it is Iran, is now striving for regional hegemony.It is certainly not in the EU's interest to create a situation where one of these powers is a regional hegemon, as this will upset the balance in this area and create new risks for Europe.I am convinced that this resolution is upsetting the balance in this very sense.On the contrary, I think we should support that balance, which is why I could not vote in favor of this resolution.I abstained.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, as I said in my speech yesterday, a huge humanitarian crisis is currently unfolding in Yemen, under the responsibility of Saudi Arabia, which has imposed a naval blockade, has also cordoned off Yemen from the air, is bombing innocent people and we have innocent victims. . The European Union has a huge responsibility. The sale of military equipment to Saudi Arabia must stop. This applies to all countries of the European Union. It also applies to Greece, which with a shameful agreement proceeds to the sale of munitions in Saudi Arabia. Greece must therefore cancel the agreement on the sale of military equipment to Saudi Arabia, an embargo must be imposed and there must be no possibility of arms exports to Saudi Arabia and, at the same time, those responsible for this humanitarian crisis and committing criminal offenses must be found. before the International Criminal Court.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, the situation in Yemen is complicated enough, and the resolution that was voted on here not only does not examine all aspects of this situation - on the contrary, it is also quite one-sided. It lacks commentary on radical Islam in its Salafi, Sunni and Shiite forms. There are enough forces in the area involved in these battles. Apart from Saudi Arabia, there is also Iran, there is Egypt, there is, of course, Turkey. We have witnessed several meetings in recent days that have fundamentally changed the balance in this part of the world. Therefore, such a resolution, if we want it to have an effect, must examine all these issues, strongly condemn the Salafist terrorism that has been exported from this region to Europe, and put these issues first. That is why I abstained. Thank you for your attention.

name: Andrejs MAMIKINS
text: – Madam President, Saudi Arabia hates their opponents in Yemen; we know the situation, and now the European position is rather strange. On the one hand, Europe is horrified by the humanitarian situation in Yemen, and on the other hand, some European countries sell weapons to Saudi Arabia. This is unacceptable, and I am really happy that today we had a majority of Members who voted in favour of embargo. This is really very important. Dear colleagues, we should choose to adhere to our European values and principles or to extract a commercial interest from this war, and we cannot combine these. Of course, I voted in favour of this report and resolution.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – Madam President, I strongly support this motion for resolution on the troubling situation in Yemen. Political negotiations are an important step towards stability in the region. While on the surface, instability in Yemen may seem like a sectarian conflict, the reality is that conflict is deeply rooted in feelings of inequality and poverty, which have worsened the deep divides in Yemeni society. The political environment is framed by the power struggle between the Houthi movement religious group and the al-Hadi Government. The situation is having dire consequences on the Yemeni people, and we must not ignore this. Between a desperate security and economic situation, which includes widespread corruption and severe food and water shortages, the Yemeni citizens are at breaking point. I believe that a mutually-acceptable political solution can resolve the current tensions, and we in the European Parliament and the European Union must do our utmost to resolve the issues quickly and effectively to avoid a civil war.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Madam President, I welcome this report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy. It rightly highlights one of the core principles of the UN’s Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities: the right to access transportation. Campaigners in my constituency from Bedfordshire Rail Access Network are dismayed that stations in Luton, Leagrave, Flitwick, Biggleswade and Harlington do not have step-free access for disabled people. Ironically, while all train carriages will have to be made accessible by 1 January 2020, there are not any plans to make four of the five Bedfordshire stations accessible. How exactly will a disabled Biggleswade passenger benefit from the accessible trains if they can’t get onto the platform? The Department for Transport has stated that, for every GBP 1 spent on access improvements, GBP 2.90 is returned in economic benefits. it is the right thing to do and makes economic sense, too. So let’s do it.

name: Krisztina MORVAI
text: - There is hardly an area of ​​human rights where there has been as much development, no breakthrough in recent decades as there has been in the area of ​​the rights of people with or with disabilities. Just think about what the chances of a child born deaf 30 years ago had a lifetime, say, and what your chances are now to live in human dignity and quality. Let us think, for example, that this report was also handed over to our hearing-impaired fellow Members, who did his job perfectly with interpretation. What I am not sure about, however, is whether a person born or suffering from a disability has the same chances in the old Member States, that is, in Western Europe and on the other side of the old Iron Curtain. For each of these policies, we should look at the extent to which cohesion is being achieved. I have a strong suspicion that, in terms of financial means, the situation is still much worse in the so-called new Member States, even if its specialists are in special education, physiotherapy, etc. they are also internationally renowned.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: - I'm holding a hearing on access to culture next week.In it, I would like to point out that access to and participation in culture is not blocked primarily by financial constraints.They are also important, but not the most important.The first obstacle is the lack of education.But in this debate that we are talking about today, there is a second point worth paying attention to.Well, we must remember that every sixth person in Europe over the age of fifteen has a disability of some sort.Due to this defect, access to culture is unfortunately very often limited.I would also like to draw attention to the problem of an aging society.These elderly people, also for physical reasons, do not have access to many institutions, many attractions offered in the world of culture, from time to time.We all know how important culture is to us.It is therefore important that you simply try to lift all these blockages.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - The report on the implementation of the European Disability Strategy has received strong support across the political spectrum. This report is really comprehensive, and I personally consider education and employment to be fundamental issues. This is what enables the integration of disabled people into the work process and into life to the full. That is why I particularly support those measures that relate to education and employment, such as the accessibility of the Erasmus + program, so that students and young people, even those with disabilities, can be involved more than ever before. I also welcome the fact that the report calls on the Commission to take certain measures, such as the accessibility of public spaces. However, I believe that these measures should remain voluntary. So, although some proposals have been adopted with which I do not agree, I voted in favor of the report because I want to express my great appreciation and respect to my colleagues who are fighting to improve conditions for people with disabilities.

name: Jiří POSPÍŠIL
text: - I supported this report because I consider it important that we want to improve the living standards of people with disabilities.I am very pleased that European policy in this area is very consistent, alongside the protection of human rights, alongside our other environmental projects.I am glad that the protection of people with disabilities, but especially their full life, is an important European political issue.I will be very happy when some good parts of this report, specific things about how to improve these people's access to education, to work, better accessibility in transport, when these things do not just stay on paper and when some of it can be put into practice.It will probably be more on specific national policies, on specific countries, that at least some of the things in this report are implemented and put into practice.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, the European strategy for supporting people with disabilities must be implemented immediately, because that is the only way to provide real support for people with disabilities in terms of health, social protection and education. I think the initiatives taken are important. But all this is a luxury for Greece, because there the Troika and the memorandum governments have literally thrown all the disabled in the social Kaiadas. They have reduced benefits for the disabled themselves and reduced benefits for the disabled. The disability movement in Greece is protesting. In fact, in August he sent a letter of protest to the Prime Minister, Mr. Tsipras, but -with the procedures that will begin in 2018- in practice, unfortunately, any benefits for people with disabilities will be reduced. Shame!
